name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. I would ask you to add a resolution to the oral question on Japanese whaling and to vote on it at the next plenary session in Strasbourg in July. Japan wants to kill, capture, slaughter nearly 4,000 whales in the coming years, whatever you want to call it. Currently, Japanese boats cross the South and Pacific Oceans. Minke whales in particular have to suffer, but the Nordic whale is also a victim.  This is an animal that can grow up to 21 meters long, one of the largest animals on our planet. This species is also threatened with extinction. It is not for nothing that an international ban on whaling has been in place since 1986. But Japan and some other countries are flouting this ban. Are we, as the European Parliament, watching the last whales being hunted and extinction, or are we doing the maximum we can to combat it? I choose the latter and I hope so.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, our group supports the request. I think it is quite clear that this is an endangered species and it is perhaps the largest mammal living on the planet today.  Many species are being extinct one after the other and therefore I think it is important that our Parliament does not lose sight of the issue of biodiversity.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, this is a request that we are not making for the first time, and the reason is the same, that this Parliament traditionally voted on human rights issues on Thursday afternoon, we even called it "the afternoon of the debate on human rights"; this debate was moved - for reasons we do not fully understand - in the morning, and then other debates were recently introduced in the afternoon, in place of this exchange on the issue of human rights emergencies. So we're just asking to go back to what we were doing until recently.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, millions of people around the world live with HIV/AIDS. We have come a long away in fighting this serious disease. However, if we are to succeed in ending the AIDS epidemic by 2030, we must speed up and beef up our efforts to prevent HIV/AIDS, to give everybody a chance of early diagnosis and to provide appropriate treatment to all those who need it.  The Commission strongly welcomes the United Nations High-Level meeting on HIV/AIDS to be held in June in New York, and supports the calls for a faster response and renewed commitment. AIDS continues to strongly affect sub-Saharan Africa. Two out of three people who become infected live there. Young girls are particularly at risk and, right here in our continent, in eastern Europe, HIV infections are still on the rise. The European Union has a role to play in bringing the AIDS epidemic to an end at home, in our neighbourhood and in other partner countries, showing solidarity and providing additional support to those countries that need it most – low income ones in particular. The EU channels its support to AIDS prevention and treatment through the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. The Fund has helped to provide HIV treatment to over eight million people. The EU and its Member States collectively provide half of the Global Fund resources: more than EUR 1.5 billion has already been contributed from the European Union budget. There are plans to pledge another EUR 470 million for the 2017—2019 period at the pledging conference in September. The Sustainable Development Goals of last year mark a welcome shift from a focus on diseases to a more integrated approach to addressing people’s health needs.  If we want to end AIDS and many other diseases, we must help third countries develop the capacity to provide basic healthcare, clean water and sanitation to all their citizens. This needs to be a collaborative effort. Domestic funding for this purpose, particularly in middle-income countries, also needs to be increased. In the EU we have made good progress: they have in particular eliminated mother-to-child transmission, and thus exposure of children to HIV/AIDS.  New infections are declining. Treatment coverage and access to care is high. A rather significant outstanding challenge remains: over 300 000 people in the EU need lifelong treatment; 30 000 people still get infected every year. Even so, HIV can be prevented. HIV/AIDS treatment costs billions of euros. The Commission works closely with Member States and civil society to strengthen prevention, improve testing and support universal access to treatment and care. We must reach out in particular to eastern Europe and Central Asia, where the epidemic is still on the rise. Again, this needs to be a collaborative effort. Tailor—made action for each of the most affected countries needs to be intensified.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome the Commissioner's presence at the plenary session and share many of the views he has expressed. The New Secretary-General of the United Nations report, "Accelerating the Response to the End of the AIDS Epidemic", warns us of the major benefits gained over the past 15 years in the fight against this threat to the health of the population, which could be lost if no action were taken over the next five years. The report also urges States to react by increasing investment and strengthening actions, especially in the prevention zone. I recall that since the beginning of the epidemic, almost 71 million people have been infected with HIV, half of whom have died over the years from failure to detect in time, lack of treatment or adequate care. Encouraging progress has been made, especially after 2011. Access to antiretroviral treatment for more than 15 million people infected with HIV has been ensured, leading to a significant increase in life expectancy, a decrease in death, and access to treatments. However, the impact of social factors such as poverty, inequality and discrimination, especially among the vulnerable population, should not be neglected. And when I say 'vulnerable population' I mean the categories of people who should no longer suffer from discrimination and, of course, first of all, I mean children. Statistics show that in the period 2000-2014, their number decreased, but there are still discrepancies, especially in developing countries. I believe that we need to have a much more ambitious plan of measures, we need to target vulnerable groups of the population, we need to create a social protection tool, we need to ensure that PEOPLE infected with HIV have access to lifelong treatment and adequate medical care.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, the United Nations conference will take note of the many progress that has been made in this area over the past fifteen years: advances in information that have led to better disease prevention, medical and pharmacological advances in responding to it, greater activation of civil society and health systems that have responded in a coordinated manner to this infection , which has taken so many millions of people ahead of the world.  But more important than the progress we have made is the commitment to continue fighting this disease that is still suffering from forty million people in the world, for which more than one million people died in 2015, from which many of their girls and women continue to become infected in different parts of the world and for which Africa — the continent of poverty and also the continent of pain — is losing many of its girls and women. Therefore, what is important are the commitments we have for the future.  And in this commitment, the most important thing is to assume what is identified by "the three 90%": that 90% of those who have the virus end up being diagnosed by health systems, that 90% of those diagnosed end up being treated and that 90% of those treated end up being free of viral infection.  I therefore believe that the European Union should push Member States to establish coordinated, national plans to prevent infection, to ensure treatment, but also to combat discrimination. And these plans need to prevent the national strategy from weakening in some countries, such as Spain, and data on the fight against AIDS are currently showing, as in Europe as a whole, an increase in infections, even if in the rest of the world they are declining.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, one of the public health priorities in 2016 is, without a doubt, the Global AIDS Fund refinancing conference. This is another appointment in addition to the one just referred to by the Commissioner. The international community has been asked to face up to its responsibilities: to let down its guard in the face of the threat posed by not only AIDS, but also other diseases such as malaria and tuberculosis, would be short-sighted. The encouraging results since the launch of the Global Fund in 2002 make a clear case for the continuation of the fight against these diseases.  It is to be hoped that not only the Commission, but also all the Member States of the European Union and all the industrialised countries, will fully understand the priorities for global public health. With regard to AIDS in particular, those who, until now, believed that they had to oppose the development of therapy, that is, access to antiretrovirals for AIDS patients, must have admitted that their exaggerated reluctance and prudence at the time would have led us straight to a dead end.  Access to care for all is no longer an illusion. It can become a lasting reality if we continue to work in the path we have been charting since the early 2000s.  The Commission has taken its responsibilities, I said, it is now up to the Member States of the European Union to do the same.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, HIV has become a global epidemic. Between 1981 and 2007 he killed nearly 25 million people and today there are still more than 30 million people affected worldwide. The Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS coordinates international efforts to act on the epidemic, and it is essential that the European Union strengthens its support for the epidemic. But supporting only in words is useless. To make it real support, we should rethly our drug development model to put it at the service of people and not the interests of large pharmaceutical companies. We must be consistent and not undermine access to medicines from the people of developing countries through trade agreements with severe intellectual property clauses that are reproduced over and over again, and we continue on that path. And patent protection is why newer and more effective medicines are not available to 95% of people affected by AIDS living in the global South. It's not my data, it's United Nations data. Finally, I would like to recall that the most common way of spreading HIV remains sexual transmission, that is, the most effective protection — even though some fanatics continue to deny it and continue to preach abstinence — is condoms. And that is how this European Parliament ruled in its 2011 Resolution, where we advocate — and read literally – for "access to means of protection such as male and female condoms, and strengthening women's rights and autonomy in sex". In short, more policy coherence and more informed and safe sex, especially for women.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, it is very promising that there are currently fewer new cases of AIDS in Africa than the number of people in treatment. It shows that if we now also invest money in the fight against AIDS and HIV, we will be able to stop this epidemic by 2020. I would like to draw attention to the fact that Eastern Europe and Central Asia are very difficult areas with regard to AIDS. Work based on human rights should be supported, taking into account the need for protection for the most vulnerable people. We need a rational drugs policy, and we must ensure that prison conditions are reasonable and also that people who do sex work have decent treatment.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, overall, the aim is to eradicate the HIV epidemic by 2012, but this will never be achieved unless african problems are tackled, especially in Central and West Africa. In these areas, access to life-saving antiretroviral treatment must be speeded up, because coverage reaches less than a third of the population that currently needs it. There are 35 countries that contribute to 90% of HIV infections worldwide. Of these, 23 are Africans. But we also have a problem in Europe; in Italy, which is in twelfth place in Europe for new diagnoses, there is clearly a problem. In 2014, 3 695 new HIV diagnoses were detected, or 6.1 cases per 100 000 in terms of incidence. Therefore, it is essential to initiate special preventive measures but also to activate new investment lines. It must be borne in mind that in low- and middle-income countries the price of medicines can reach up to 80 times the international reference price. In these countries there is very little availability in the public sector, while there is a great deal of availability in the private sector, where prices are much higher, thus making themselves inaccessible to huge slices of the population. We have a problem with access to medicines, to medicines, in Africa and, at the same time, we have a problem of over-medicine in rich countries. Above all, we have an excess of concentration in the industrial production of medicines, which is all in the hands of very few pharmaceutical companies that have the power to decide on price, the power to lay down rules for intellectual property rights and the power to promote incremental innovations rather than real research. Clearly, the HIV virus is not economically attractive enough for these pharmaceutical companies, and that is scandalous for us.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Commissioner for his very strong statement and commitment to solving the problem of HIV/AIDS, both here in Europe and globally. It is very important for the EU to play a strong, committed and internationally leading role. Indeed, there is a challenge, but in the midst of this, it should be remembered that the whole fight against HIV is a good example of how international cooperation can co-operation and develop medicines for severe diseases, improve prevention, reduce stigma and also extend life expectancy in those who have fallen ill. Of course, this is not enough.  In order to really stop the spread of AIDS, I believe that we have four aspects that need to be addressed in the EU's actions. The first is, of course, the prevention mentioned here, including the sexual rights and education of women and girls. The second powerful issue relates to social justice and the human rights aspect. We need information, training and stigma-free care, prevention and communication. As we know, on many occasions these problems are also associated with social disadvantage, crime or otherwise desperate situations, and I therefore hope that the EU will also be able to invest more generally in this strengthening of the social aspect and well-being.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President, the truth, according to the United Nations report and we can all see this, is that progress has been very important in the treatment and prevention of AIDS. However, as the report says, we cannot be complacent because progress over the past fifteen years can be put to a back end if we do not make the effort required by this end of what we might call the 'AIDS epidemic'.  Nearly forty million people remain infected, and twenty-two million of them are still unable to access treatment. Here in Parliament we are opening up a debate on access to medicines and, of course, we must incorporate this aspect into the whole policy of development cooperation. Women and girls are mainly the most affected; therefore, a gender approach is essential.  In Europe, low- and middle-income countries still have the challenge ahead. In addition, I would like to make a warning about the possibility that we will see an uptick in this situation of economic crisis, where the pattern of drug use is changing: cocaine for heroin, which is cheaper and which, as you know, leads to so many infectious diseases.  So, we can't let our guard down. The European Union has to play its leadership role, it has to have an ambitious goal to eradicate this epidemic by 2030; we need to aim for national plans that eradicate and prevent these viral diseases as a whole and, of course, we need to strengthen our health system, which is so important to ensure universality for all citizens in order to combat this and all the epidemics ahead.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that enormous progress has been made in the fight against the human immunodeficiency virus, as the Commissioner said very well. Today, almost sixteen million people are medicated with antiretrovirals, which equates to a reduction of about 35% in new infections compared to 2000.As well as the decrease in HIV-related fatalities since the peak of the epidemic in the order of 42%. However, different data show that there is still much to do if we want to restore dignity and quality of life to all those with HIV. Data that indicate that about twenty-two million people still do not have access to adequate medication and that half of all carriers of viruses are unaware of their real situation. Ladies and gentlemen, at the beginning of this new millennium we cannot allow inequities to remain in response to HIV. Ending the AIDS epidemic by 20-30 is now a difficult but possible goal. To this end, we need to be able to implement, in the next five years, a coordinated and comprehensive strategy based on the number of key pillars that give priority to the joint mobilization of funding and the anticipation of the necessary investments in the fight against HIV, with particular attention to countries with greater weaknesses in their health systems, as well as to groups most exposed to the risk of infection , as well as the assumption that the prevention element is absolutely paradigmatic in the fight against HIV, and therefore more resources should be allocated to it.  Commissioner, only through an integrated and comprehensive approach can we achieve a virtuous cycle of progress in this fight, and i therefore want to commend the UN initiative, hoping that the European Union will also be able to join forces to materialise this millennium development goal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – The European Union and the participants in this high-level meeting must make binding commitments to: end the discrimination and social stigma suffered by people who are still ill with ISIS and to eliminate existing laws in some countries that criminalise people with the virus, ensure universal access to public health and sexual and reproductive health services , as well as medicines, ending the monopoly of the pharmaceutical industry and the shameful patent business, as well as avoiding further contagions. To eradicate the disease, much more reinforcements are needed in the field of prevention and pay close attention to young people and adolescents. Research should be public and at the service of people, rather than handing over public money to an industry it employs to favour its interests above the right to health.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – My question is simply this. I completely understand where you are coming from in suggesting that pharmaceutical companies are charging incredibly high prices for antiretrovirals, and I further understand where you are coming from in saying that this has an impact on the fight against HIV and AIDS. What I would like to know more about is what specifically you suggest that the United Nations should do about this problem at the high level meeting at the end of this week?

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: "blue card" response. – Thank you for your question, Mr Arnott. I think I have already said in my speech quite clearly that the European Union and industrialised powers must be committed to ending the patent business and allowing the production of medicines at affordable prices and costs.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, this year marks the 35th anniversary of the first, on the scientific basis of recorded HIV infection. When it comes to HIV, early diagnosis and timely treatment are crucial, but education and prevention are even more important. Values-based education and responsible behaviour will help make our children responsible young people, so it needs to be invested in. Responsible behaviour is even more important to talk about today as we face worrying trends that show how more children and young people aged 10-19 are contracting HIV. To date, more than 30 million people have died from HIV, but international experts confirm that AIDS could disappear as a threat to public health by 2030 when at least 90% of people infected with HIV would be diagnosed in a timely way and start antiretroviral treatment. In order to meet this goal, it is necessary to reach the most vulnerable and the poorest. 22 million people still don't have access to the treatment, and most don't even know they're infected. Nearly 26 million people are estimated to be infected with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa. Religious organizations play a major role in hiv testing and treatment, especially in this part of the world, and international Caritas has taken a leading role in promoting care for people affected by HIV.  Two months ago, Caritas and religious organizations also issued guidelines for eradicating HIV in children by 2020. Although the number of patients and child mortality decreased in recent years, and more than 70% of infected pregnant women received treatment so that the virus would not be transmitted to children, the treatment is available only for 820 thousand children out of 2.6 million who are infected with HIV.  International Caritas and religious organizations work with world-renowned experts, have developed research programs, their methods are effective, but they lack money. We have the financial resources, let's put them in the right hands!

name: Soraya POST
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The social stigma and sometimes even the regular discrimination suffered by HIV sufferers in health care, in the workplace and in education is still widespread and represents a great deal of psychological suffering for many. Discriminatory laws and policies regarding HIV-infected people must be discontinued and adequate information on HIV must be widely disclosed in society.  HIV prevention is a shared responsibility and should be targeted at all groups in society. The greatest risk of the spread of HIV is precisely the stigma that leads to many people not finding out the information or dare to seek care. In the fight against and prevention of HIV, human rights therefore need to be at the centre and proper efforts should be made to combat stigma and discrimination against HIV sufferers. Last year, the WHO registered several new HIV infections in Europe since the 1980s: 142 000. In the EU, around two million people are responsible for the infection. In Europe, we need politicians at national and local level to take on the fight against HIV. There is a need for more investment in health care, increased funding for prevention, syringe exchange programmes and, of course, more support for third countries.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, promoting the support of the European Union and its citizens to the objectives of the United Nations to eradicate AIDS as a threat to public health in 2030 is for me reason, but also emotion. Because in the 1980s, in Bermeo, the small fishing village where I was born, this disease killed too many people I shared desks with, adolescence, that I tried about you. Too many people who, in spaces and shared times, discovered the drug and suffered the disease, the death associated with those two fearsome syllables that were whispered at each funeral.  But I also experienced a rebellion that began mothers, women, denunciation, social and institutional involvement, hope, rigor and victory. And I want the same opportunity, the same relief, for all of us facing an enemy now visible and known that can only be rearmed if we waste what we have already achieved.  AIDS survives today in poverty, marginalization, prejudice and inequality. She mostly has a woman's face. And it's an ambush watch bomb in what we call third world, but also in Eastern Europe. Let us disable it by avoiding the vetoes that fundamentalism wants to impose on the most active and useful associations at this summit; ensuring that at least 90% of HIV-positive people know that they are, that at least 90% of them are being treated by 2030, and that 90% of treaties have an undetectable viral burden. That is why I call for "zero cuts" against AIDS, active citizens, laws that do not hinder access to treatment for risky populations, more equality, more empowered women and humanity. One last effort to reach a goal we have at our fingertips.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would also like to start with the word prevention, of course. Prevention, prevention. However, I think that the Commissioner's statement is worth appreciating. I would like to appreciate the role of the European Union in this field, because, as the Commissioner has also stressed, half of the contributions allocated to the Fund precisely to combat not only HIV/AIDS, but also other major diseases, tuberculosis and others, are contributions from EU Member States. I think that's really commendable and I think it's important to highlight it at this point.  In my opinion, it is on this disease that we can see how much development medicine has undergone. In the 1980's and 1990's, HIV/AIDS was an incurable deadly disease. It is now treatable to some extent, but I think it is a disease that any of us would be afraid to acquire. And I think it is important to say in this field that in Eastern Europe people have stopped worrying. In one year, 120,000 newly infected, I think, shows a lot, and the goal that has been set – to eradicate this disease by 2030 – is very ambitious, but with such a procedure, it is clear that it will not be achieved. I think more should be invested in research. And, of course, the prevention that many of my colleagues have talked about here.  Unfortunately, my country, the Czech Republic, is also failing a lot in this context. We have suppressed various prevention programs and now it is coming back to us, we have the most infected since the infections in this area began to be measured in our country. That is why it is important to talk about the fact that the European Union should not only invest money in the fight against this disease, but also in research and support those states that are in the opposite sphere of poverty, i.e. those that they really cannot provide for their infected medicines.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! I have speaking time of one minute and 30 seconds, and while I am speaking, three people die of AIDS. Globally, one person dies every 30 seconds. There are 40 million people infected worldwide and another two million are added every year. Fortunately, the good story is that we agree with the world that we need to do something about this. We need to eradicate the AIDS epidemic before we get to 2030, and we also know well from the 2015 targets, The Millennium Goals, that there is no point in achieving these objectives, because then we will also act accordingly. Nevertheless, it is alarming when we read the UN report on this matter. The Un says that if we continue to act and act and make the actions we are taking at this stage, then we will actually see even more people infected. In other words, much, much more action is needed! A great deal of things are needed: more money is needed, there is a need for better access to medicines, but the medicine is not enough in itself, because in many of the people who are given the medicine, it will not work if they do not also receive food at the same time. And then we need information, information, information! It is extremely important that the problem of what causes AIDS is addressed. I am very pleased that the Commission and the Member States of the European Union support the idea that we should have AIDS on the agenda even more than we have done so far. This is necessary if we are to do something about the epidemic.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Between 2009 and 2014, the number of children infected with HIV fell by 45%. The number of women who died of AIDS also fell by a third. However, prevention in women of childbearing potential and the application of four pre-birth examinations as recommended by the WHO remain a challenge. The problem is also that, for example, in the most affected countries of Africa, only half of children exposed to HIV undergo diagnostic screening after birth. More than a quarter of all care for people suffering from HIV and AIDS worldwide is provided by Catholic health institutions. They see their work as a moral obligation because they believe that every human life, even the one not yet born, is worthy of protection. For example, a team of doctors and healthcare professionals from the Slovak University of St. Elizabeth from Bratislava has long led health projects in Africa and Asia dedicated to children with HIV and their mothers. However, dialogue between these organisations and the EU is hampered by dogma about ending pregnancy as a solution to any political or health problem. In doing so, ending the life of a child at risk of HIV is neither prevention nor treatment. What the baby needs to be born healthy are medications already during pregnancy and in the first weeks after childbirth. The experience of working on the ground confirms that a family based on an equal partnership between one man and one woman is much more important in the fight against HIV and AIDS than abortion clinics. Because such a family teaches both responsibilities in a relationship and duty of care to family members.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr First of all, I would like to thank the Commission for what the Commission is doing in terms of AIDS prevention, and indeed we are doing a lot here within the European Union. We have the best medicines, the most advanced technologies in Europe. We know how we can win this fight. But unfortunately, the figures show that the highest percentage of patients is among young people. These are terrible numbers. I can tell you about this when it comes to my country, Latvia, because here the biggest increase in percentage is because young people use drugs – at first legal drugs, so-called spas, and then also use drugs intravenously, which only increases the percentage of AIDS patients. Of course, thanks to the World Health Organization, for example, three great centers in the capital City of Riga, Liepaja and Daugavpils have been opened in Latvia, but unfortunately these prevention measures are not available to people in rural areas. And yet it should be noted that this situation in my country and in eastern European countries is better than it was in the early 1990s after the collapse of the USSR. And yet, globally, it is clear that 90% of AIDS patients, even children, are in sub-Sahara (South Africa, Namibia, Botswana), and it should be noted that it is imperative that we fight against so-called religious cults when sex with an innocent young person is considered to be [graduation], which is also the cause of aids.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I also want to welcome the Commissioner to the Chamber this evening and I welcome his work on this. It is important that the UN and the EU work as partners as we approach the High-Level Meeting. As others have said, a huge amount has been done in this area in recent years, but we still have exceptionally large numbers of people across the globe who have to live with the reality of AIDS. Forty million people have been affected. The reality is that 16 million people at least are living with AIDS as a consequence of having antiretroviral drugs following proper testing.  I would make one point in this debate and it is this: I think we have become complacent in the European Union on the prevalence of AIDS. In my own country the numbers last year were at the highest level of new cases for the past five years. At least one-third of people in Ireland are not even aware that they are prone to obtain the virus and are possible carriers of the virus. So we have got to do much more within Europe to address the issue while supporting the United Nations, as we do in this area.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, AIDS has set the global agenda for health policies for an entire generation. The first AIDS deaths were diagnosed over thirty years ago and HIV quickly became a global tragedy. At present, of the 36.7 million people living with HIV, less than half access specific health treatments.  A concrete approach requires the setting of ambitious targets at short deadlines that take into account, at the same time, prevention policies aimed at reducing the number of people infected, health policies to reduce the number of people dying of AIDS and social policies to eliminate discrimination related to HIV infection. It is to be hoped that at the next high-level meeting of the United Nations in New York bold decisions will be taken that leave no one behind, because it is clear that the fight against AIDS depends only on the effectiveness of the policies put in place. The technology, medicines and tools at our disposal are able to achieve the goal set with the adoption of the UN agenda to eradicate the epidemic by 2030. For this to happen, however, it is necessary for these available instruments to be more and concretely available to everyone, including in poor countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, we welcome the forthcoming meeting of representatives of governments and the structures for implementing programmes to combat HIV/AIDS to be held from 8 to 10 June at the United Nations headquarters in New York. The results of recent HIV/AIDS research are particularly worrying, as it turns out that 36.9 million people worldwide live with HIV/AIDS. Africa remains the global epicenter of the pandemic with 25.8 million people being AIDS carriers in 2014. Despite a large increase in global funding to tackle HIV/AIDS since 2000, HIV/AIDS remains on the rise, with 38.4 million of our fellow human beings infected, demonstrating that the resources available to tackle HIV/AIDS are still insufficient. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to invest funds in research into the production of powerful and effective medicines to tackle AIDS, and care must be taken to ensure that as much of the world's population as possible has access to appropriate information, prevention, advice, medical checks and AIDS treatment.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, on one personal example I experienced in the 1990s, I want to show how open the conversation is, the awareness of the problems of HIV, AIDS or AIDS and the fact that sufferers, especially when it was in the 1990s, can very well become a problem for the environment in which he lives, where his children go to school, because his wife also moves around the small town where this good acquaintance of mine once lived.  Unfortunately, he's gone because back then the drugs were almost non-existent. This just wants to emphasize one fact. We need to invest as much as we can in education, invest as much as we can in prevention. As a European Union, we should be leaders in this, as we are today, to continue to do so, because only in this way, by nurturing open awareness and the public about this problem and investing in medicines, in education, in prevention can we solve this great epidemic.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for a fruitful debate. Many of you mentioned very important issues: early diagnosis, early treatment and prevention measures, Triple-90, national drug policies, human rights dimensions and social determinants in the world, poverty and sexual exploitation, access to treatment, pricing and patent issues, the reproductive health and sexual rights of girls and women, the fight against stigmatisation, education and prophylaxis, research and investment in treatment, and socially affordable prices. Thank you very much indeed for your contributions. All those things are very important.  It is clear that the fight against HIV is not over, despite the amazing progress we have made over the past decades. It is also clear that we will one day succeed together. HIV affects all countries, regardless of their capacities to respond to the challenge. HIV also affects the most vulnerable and does not stop at national borders. That is why we need collective action and solidarity with the vulnerable living among us and those living in countries that cannot afford universal healthcare coverage. The Commission will continue to support EU action to address HIV within the EU, in the neighbouring countries and across the world, using all the tools at its disposal. In that sense, I am confident that the United Nations high-level meeting later this week will serve to send a strong and united message from the European Union.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would first like to thank the other political groups for the excellent cooperation we have had, as well as Commissioner Andriukaitis, for being here today to discuss the coherence of the Union's policies for development (CPD). CPD is a very important, complex and little-known subject. It is about the consistency of all our policies, so it is tempting to want to deal with everything. It seems to me that Parliament's report did not give in to this temptation and tried to focus on a few key elements, both to move the debate forward and to contribute to the implementation of the CPD. Within the Union, coherence is very important: the different institutions want to be coherent with each other; we also want our policies to be consistent with each other. The most difficult question is how to implement this coherence in the service of development so as not to undo on the one hand what we do on the other.  The Commission's 2015 report is positive: there has been considerable progress, which must, of course, be both continued and strengthened. In Parliament's resolution, we focused on two key points. First, there is the interaction between the CPD and the development agenda by 2030. While other international actors have already begun a thorough reflection on the transformation of the CPD into 'coherence of policies in the service of sustainable development', the European Union has yet to adopt a clear position on this point. The drafting of this report and the workshop we organised were an opportunity for Parliament to launch this process of reflection. The fact that the European Commission is embarking on a similar process could call into question the very principle of the CPD and the biennial report, with a broader perspective.  Designing the CPD as part of the 2030 development agenda also means rethinking global development goals to evade this donor-receiver concept and move towards goals that are applicable to all.  The CPD remains an unknown concept at the international level. We will not be able to integrate the CPD into the Sustainable Development Goals if the other key players in development - the United States, Japan, the BRICS - do not participate in this effort. The Union has a key role to play. It must continue to promote the universalization of the CPD concept to our partners. The European Parliament must be involved in this process, as it is now an important player in the CPD.  The second crucial element in this year's report is to find ways to improve the use and effectiveness of CPD instruments. I think it is important to stress that the implementation of the CPD remains laborious, but we must not forget that it is a complex exercise.  I did not call for the creation of new instruments for the CPD, because the necessary instruments already exist. On the other hand, we must find a way to use these tools in the most consistent and effective way possible. This requires clear and indisputable responsibilities for the implementation of the CPD. The only way to give the CPD a decisive boost is to put it on the agenda of an EU summit. I know the idea can make you smile, but a few years ago there was also a smile on the idea of organising a European defence summit. If we really want to be serious about the progress of the CPD, it must be discussed at the highest political level. An EU summit would also create an inter-institutional and Member State-level thought process. This summit would provide clear guidance on how to operationalize the CPD. It must be able to extract itself from the "development" bubble in order to exist in other areas. It's not about development, it's about coordinating all the other policies for development. So we have to think differently about the CPD.  Since the 2013 report, new instruments have been created. I am thinking in particular of the contribution of the European Union delegations to the biennial report. This exercise is a positive development, which should be extended to all delegations. Moreover, in view of the extremely important role that EU heads of delegations can play in implementing the CPD on the ground, this issue should be put on the agenda of the annual meeting of heads of delegations in Brussels. Delegations have a comprehensive view of EU policies in a given country and can therefore enable us to identify inconsistencies and how to correct them.  Of course, I cannot mention here all the instruments of the CPD and how to improve them. We still have a lot of progress to make in terms of impact studies, for example, which are not conducted systematically. But I also want to say that some instruments work, and even very well. I am thinking in particular of joint programming, which includes not only all the activities of the Union but also the activities of the Member States, to ensure greater coherence.  Of course, I cannot address all the priority areas of action contained in the report. Should the CPD's priorities be changed, or should others be added? I think we will be able to answer that question once we have started the process of reflection as part of the implementation of the development agenda by 2030. Finally, I would like to add that I wanted to focus this year on the CPD in the Union's foreign policy. The refugee crisis, the destabilization facing the Union in its neighbourhood, have called into question its very foundations, including solidarity and free movement. External action is the area on which the CPD must focus. Stabilizing our neighbourhood must therefore be a top priority. We have the comprehensive approach, which is an ideal instrument for the CPD, and this approach should be further strengthened with the adoption of the comprehensive strategy this month. We must make this instrument the hallmark of the European Union's external action.  The comprehensive approach, when properly implemented, should also enable us to prevent crises and ensure an effective transition from a military or civilian operation to the implementation of other instruments to continue progress on the ground. The example of the Sahel speaks for itself. When the Union mobilises all its tools in a region facing poverty, internal conflict and radicalisation, it can make a difference.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, policy coherence for development is, indeed, of fundamental importance in our joint efforts to promote and support global sustainable development. Ensuring that all European Union policies contribute to our shared development objective is not only common sense but also a necessity. In the Commission we have put policy coherence at the heart of our work, both in terms of ensuring coherence of our general policies and actions and in making sure that our policies indeed support our development cooperation objectives. But we cannot do this alone: we need to join forces. It is a shared responsibility. It is very encouraging to see this Parliament’s strong interest in and support for policy coherence for development, as manifested by this debate. Let me thank the rapporteur, Mr Preda, for steering the preparation of the report, which we welcome. The European Parliament has a key role to play in making policy coherence for development a success. You have consistently underlined the importance of the topic, including by establishing the post of standing rapporteur and by issuing several important resolutions. This debate is both useful and very timely. It provides an important contribution not only in our daily business of implementing policy coherence for development but more importantly for the implementation of the watershed 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The universal character of the 2030 Agenda marks a fundamental change of paradigm. It calls for a whole-of-government approach and for development sensitivity in policy making across a very broad range of inter-connected sectors. The most important challenge for all of us in this room and well beyond is to make it happen, putting all means at our disposal to good use. This is what we are currently working on in the context of the revision of the European Consensus on Development. A public consultation was launched last week and will be open until 21 August. We count very strongly on your input and support. Despite some critical remarks, which we note and also appreciate, I welcome the overall positive assessment by this House of the Commission’s work on policy coherence for development (PCD). We have made significant progress over the last years. Let me give you some examples of where our work has successfully influenced political decision making in favour of development objectives. First, we have placed PCD firmly as a part of impact assessments within the Better Regulation framework. It is still early days, but the systematic development check, through development specific guidelines and a toolbox for assessing potential impacts when elaborating new initiatives, has the potential to be a game changer. We have introduced country-by-country reporting, increasing transparency in extractive industries. The last common agricultural policy reform of 2013 was mindful of potential trade distortions vis-à-vis developing countries. And, finally, the Commission communication on ‘Trade for All’, from October 2015, was drafted with significant pro-development considerations as guiding principles. In short, we are making progress and this is confirmed by the 2015 PCD report and by your report today. We should be encouraged by that. We should continue to step up our joint efforts to make full use of policy coherence for development as a tool for implementing the 2030 Agenda and guaranteeing the shared prosperity of the European Union and our partner countries.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Mr President, the coherence of policies beyond a principle set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and in the United Nations' own sustainable development objectives is pure common sense. Consistency must or should be the cornerstone of our entire foreign policy. Some Members of this House have their mouths filled by talking about resource efficiency and efficiency, but, ladies and gentlemen, policy coherence is a key issue for efficiency. If we are not consistent in our external action, we are wasting money for official development aid and also deceiving citizens who, with their taxes, finance these aids. Because while we are allocating development aid, the rest of our policies, especially trade, continue to impoverish the countries of the south. And so, what we give with one hand we take away with the other. It's a totally cynical and hypocritical posture. It is now, once the SDGs have been approved, that it is time to move from policy to action. The universal nature of the new development framework implies that we, the developed countries, place an emphasis on policy coherence. It is time to be ambitious, to go beyond the beautiful words and to bet on truly effective and above all binding measures, such as betting on international taxation, combating austerity policies and privatizations of public services, demanding civil and criminal liability from large companies and ending their unbearable impunity, reformulating trade and investment policy , putting it at the service of people, or ensuring access to medicines as a universal and fundamental right. This is a very important opportunity for the European Parliament to become aware of the principle of policy coherence for development and to call for the urgency of effective and, as I said, binding measures to ensure the full implementation of Article 208 which, ladies and gentlemen, we have given ourselves and are not complying with. It is regrettable to see how the Conservative Group and the People's Group, through separate votes, are trying to dilute the most necessary elements of this report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. President, at the outset, I would like to thank our permanent rapporteur, Mr. Preda, for a report that I think will be adopted by an overwhelming majority in Parliament. He has already stressed, I will reiterate, that our development cooperation is indeed needed to be effective, the coherence of all EU policies in the interest of sustainable development is needed. And indeed a lot has been done in this area, for example as far as the alignment of our agricultural policy is concerned. The fact is that our trade policy must also be aligned, but I would not share such critical tones as my colleague mentioned before me.  It seems to me that free trade is one key growth generator for developing countries. That the benefits of free trade are more numerous, and the most obvious is the generation of economic growth through increased commercial opportunities and investments and increasing the productive base through the development of the private sector. And I think that should also be taken into account.  In any case, coherence between the European Union's policies and development goals is a key element, and we all agree, to achieve the new 2030 agenda for sustainable development and we must not fall into the trap of giving one hand in the form of development aid and taking the other through some other policies. That's right. I might point out the issue of illicit financial flows and perhaps we should also work a little harder in this area, especially in the framework and in the form of new Panama papers that have been published.  So that's where we need some new mechanisms, too. But this in no case means that development policy should be abandoned, but that our focus in these development policies and in other policies, internal and external, should focus precisely on fighting corruption, promoting good rule as the basic preconditions for sustainable and just development.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Preda for the report and for finding consensus on it. I just want to focus on one aspect of policy coherence for development: that is tax issues. Mr Preda mentioned the agreement on the sustainable development goals (SDGs) and that, of course, was underpinned by the agreement on the financing for development. A big part of that is domestic resource mobilisation by developing countries, but we will not achieve that unless we see big changes in the international tax system: unless we close down tax loopholes and illicit financial flows. Thabo Mbeki came to the Committee on Development a few weeks ago and he told us how staggering amounts of money leak out of Africa into tax havens and into European bank accounts. This has to stop, and that is why we have a chance in this Parliament to vote to change these rules: to make sure that African countries, and other developing countries, can raise their own financing for development, and to make sure that we have this Special Committee on the Panama papers, so that policy coherence for development is much more than a box-ticking exercise , and leads to genuine change.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! When I speak on this report, it is particularly because of the section on migration. I think it is perfectly logical for the rapporteur to choose to make a link between the foreign aid we are funding and the need for better coordination of migration, not least because, if we did not have the uncontrolled migration, there would be much more money to actually help those people in need who do not manage to get to Europe. But what I always wonder about when I read these reports is that, without fleshing out the content, common solutions are being called for. Surely the rapporteur must have an opinion on what the common solution should be. A solution is not good simply because it is common! And I have to say that if I look around among the 28 countries today, the only thing – or at least the one that can garner the greatest support – seems to be a push model, focusing more on helping those people in the neighbourhoods who are genuinely in physical distress, who cannot afford to bribe people smugglers who do not want to risk their lives across the Mediterranean. than focusing on those who have come to Europe by that route. So I would like to see a greater focus on helping in the immediate areas, rather than what we are doing here.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, the European Parliament's Development Committee is presenting its third report today on policy coherence for development. There is no need to repeat the same observations, the same analyses and the same proposals, all of which have already been said and repeated. In fact, Cristian Preda, whom I congratulate, has resisted this temptation. What is important is to learn from them, which should guide us in action. To that end, I have tabled an oral amendment which, if implemented, would allow the President of the Commission to decide in the event that two or more commission departments fail to agree on the way forward.  It can be argued that the Commission's inter-service meetings are there to resolve this kind of conflict; the question is what should be done in the event of an insurmountable divergence. From my point of view, arbitration must be provided at a higher hierarchical level: in this case, the possibility should be provided for the President of the Commission to assume full political responsibility on the main directions. It could thus decide under the commitments made by the European Union in the context of policy coherence in the service of development. I would like to stress the importance of this oral amendment. Indeed, not to retain it or, if necessary, to oppose it, would be to question a provision that the European Parliament had already voted by its vast majority in my own report on the coherence of policies in the service of development discussed here in plenary in 2013. The reason for a more coherent policy is less and less disputed, which is increasingly accepted, is now on how we should focus our efforts and that is why I have introduced this oral amendment.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, after reading this report I am surprised, as a first impression, by the constant link between development and security, often including the European External Action Service by means. In addition, the report is full of nice words and good intentions: it proposes, for example, impact assessments on the coherence of development policies, but without demanding any legally binding policies or decisions.  Furthermore, the report underlines concern about the current migration crisis (as the report calls it) and proposes a sectarian solution to this phenomenon, rather than addressing the causes of this increase in migration and, moreover, without regard to the economic, cultural and social benefits that immigration brings to our countries, as various studies have shown. Anyway, a lot of nice words and not so pretty and few acts. A "more of the same".

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to thank Mr Preda for his excellent report and the good cooperation we have had on it in the Committee on Development.  I think Commissioner Andriukaitis said something very important when he talked about the interconnectedness of things and how they should be reflected in the ways decisions are planned and taken. I am very happy to hear that the Commissioner is saying that, for instance, policy coherence for development could in the future be a part of impact assessments. Let me also support the oral amendment by Mr Goerens, which says that, when in the Commission two or more Commissioners do not agree on something that has a serious impact – positive or negative – on development, the President of the Commission could have a role. I very much agree and we should develop something similar here in Parliament. But, at the same time, elsewhere, something quite different is going on. I have become aware of the fact that the Commission and the External Action Service have now agreed that development cooperation money could be used to acquire and purchase weapons in those third countries where the EU is training the military. I think it is outrageous to hear that we would do this at the cost of development financing. Before anything like this is undertaken we should definitely have more funds to use, and we should make sure that these armies and military and police forces in developing countries get sufficient training in a human-rights-based approach and a democratic way of working.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we all do indeed have a human duty. There are 1.5 billion people in this world who are still living in poverty, who are deprived in ways that we in the West can only imagine. We have a human duty to do what we can to help, but to me this report is far from ideal in terms of identifying the problems at European Union level, and also in terms of seeking what solutions we should adopt.  The discussion of migration and development seems to spectacularly fail to take into account the way that the European Union has, in my view, mismanaged the refugee crisis from start to finish. The problems that arose are problems which could reasonably have been foreseen at the time, and which many of us did in fact foresee and said on the record, in this place, at the time.  It seems to me that this report is pushing towards greater EU, more EU control. For example, it mentions common asylum and immigration policy. I just wonder, if people in the United Kingdom actually knew that there were moves in this place towards a common asylum and immigration policy, how that would impact on their views on 23 June? Where I do agree with the report is to say that aid alone is not sufficient, because a lot of assisting development in developing countries is actually about developing through trade. It is actually about eliminating tariff barriers of which, sadly, we still all too often have too many at EU level. It is about bringing down tariff barriers and it is about helping countries through free and fair trade.  I would take issue as well with the report in its mention of a financial transaction tax. I see that as something that is hugely unconnected to the development issue and something which again would go down very badly indeed within the United Kingdom. So I would say that whilst I agree with the principle of the human duty that we have, this report has spectacularly failed to achieve what it should have achieved. The UK is actually quite efficient compared with other EU countries in this regard, and my fear is that we end up being brought down to the lowest common denominator.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, development means combining capital and the work of men. Development is done by men, but is not decreed. Twenty years of practice in Africa have taught me this, because training and the transfer of know-how must go hand in hand with the transfer of capital: it takes time and programming. Real development is organized, planned and financed, for a long-term return on investment that does not meet the law of the market and generalized competition, which, for its part, has only short-term prospects and therefore does not invest in human capital.  Europe and Africa have in common that they have been victims of austerity imposed by debt and thus by finance, which has taken over the real economy, the human economy that makes development: Africa by the IMF, in the context of the debt crisis of the 1980s, and Europe, in that of the sovereign debt crisis that followed the banking crisis of 2007-2008.  We should remember the Jewish Jubilee, which handed over debts every 50 years to regain the human sense of the economy. To do this, we would have to get out of our slogans of the single market, which is really unique in an almost programmed bankruptcy.  I propose a real "New Deal" for Europe and Africa, using the resources of the Central Bank not to buy debts, but to create, this time, new wealth.  A trillion invested in southern Europe, because even though the balance of payments accounts are currently balanced, this has been done by the destruction of wealth as a result of austerity. This trillion will enable France, Italy, Greece, Portugal and Spain to return to jobs and growth.  Five hundred billion for Africa and the Middle East, because wealth creation in these countries is essential if we are to stop poverty immigration and ensure that men have the right to live and develop at home.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, the coherence of development policy is another example of the distance between the perspective of the European Union and reality. Nothing you theoretically seek has been achieved. The situation is clearly worse than it was a decade ago, and the prospects are far from good. Certain countries of the Union, first of all Greece, are experiencing an economic and social disaster that largely stems from the political incompetence of Europe's experts. Needless to say, this report raises the concern of its author about meeting the needs of illegal immigrants, suspected NGOs and other voluntary organisations rather than European citizens.  As far as developing countries are concerned, the aid offered to them is nothing more than a neo-colonial policy with a development wrapper. You make full acceptance by third countries of your own values and control a prerequisite for financial aid, even having the audacity to call them universal. A comprehensive redefinition of the Union's economic policy is needed to serve the needs of European citizens, not multinationals. As far as our external relations are concerned, it has been shown that the less Europe intervenes, the better for everyone.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – I support mr Preda's report, which calls for greater involvement of the European Parliament in development policy, highlighting migration, trade and finance, the environment, agriculture and international cooperation, both in the Member States and with the United States and the BRIC countries. The European Parliament should support the Coherent Development Policy Initiative, the main objective of which is an effective long-term development agenda.  The Predy report also includes mechanisms on how the European Parliament has supported the implementation of policy coherence for development and the very important role of the relevant documentation necessary for the effective monitoring of the actions taken by the European Parliament and the Member States. The amendment to the 2030 Agenda proposed in the report stresses the need to set universal targets for all countries, departing from the model of developed countries as donors and developing countries as recipients. As demonstrated by the CONCORD Group's research, most countries do not carry out analyses to assess the impact of TD actions, which makes it difficult to assess the effectiveness of the policies we implement. Mr Preda's report, suggesting that Member States carry out more thorough research specifically on the impact of cohesion policy actions on development, also proposes another solution: the introduction of an arbitration system under the direct guidance of a Representative of the Commission, acting in the event of divergences between the various actions of the European Union and an independent complaints system for citizens of developing countries directly affected by the actions of the European Union.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the coherence of development policies is contained in the Lisbon Treaty and is therefore a constitutional mandate for the European Union, which we are politically obliged to put in place. However, this is not the case. We're not getting it going. Every Union policy is on its side and yet we need that coherence at institutional level within the Union and in connection with national policies. We need to strengthen ties with national parliaments to better monitor the development policies of the respective governments. 2016 is a key year to get to work, because it is the year when we need to start implementing the Sustainable Development Goals. We need to implement what has been decided at the Istanbul World Humanitarian Summit and other commitments on debt effectiveness. It does not fit here, as in the biblical text, that what the left hand does does not know the right hand. On the contrary, it is both hands that have to work together on trade, development and taxation issues.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, humanity is plagued by poverty and underdevelopment. At least 1.5 billion of our fellow human beings live in poverty and poverty and lack basic health and education benefits, while at the same time global wealth accumulates in a handful of people. But instead of the European Union focusing on sustainable development, reducing poverty and huge social inequalities on the world stage, it is finally continuing to stick to the policy of austerity and exploitation. The European Union must therefore change course and establish a coherent development policy, strengthening poor producers, cooperatives and small businesses, promoting fair trade and debt write-off of developing world countries and countries in the European region, in particular Greece, which is plagued by the troika's memoranda. At the same time, the European Union should monitor the impact of its agricultural and energy policy on the living standards of populations, ensure a reduction in income inequalities, an effective health system for all and measures to implement the COP21 Paris Agreement on climate change.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – In recent years, the European Anti-Fraud Office has identified Olaf for €900 million worth of fraud. That's almost a billion.  But anyone who has been around here for more than three days knows that you have to multiply that amount by seven, such as the number of refugees or the depth of the Greek crisis. That's way, way too much money. And it's the same countries every time. It's almost starting to look like the Eurovision Song Contest!  I ask the Commissioner to return this money to the people to whom it belongs, and that is the taxpayers of the net-paying countries. It cannot be that these people work hard, pay a lot of tax and that billions a year are wasted on fraud.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today we are discussing one of the most important topics of the times in which we live. Unfortunately, I am afraid that many people underestimate this. It is therefore all the more important to thank the rapporteur, Mr Preda, and what he has touched on in his report.  Many of the speakers here are receiving the subject we are talking about, only in humanitarian terms - humanitarian and charitable aid. However, this is a matter of civilisation. We live in a time of great breakthrough. Behind us is the globalisation of the exploitation of one another, that is, the globalisation of poverty. We must set ourselves a very important objective, that is, the globalisation of prosperity. The globalisation of prosperity is not only a blank slogan, or such a humane treatment of those who are poorer than us, but it is also a purely economic and economic challenge. The world will not be able to function long being divided into a rich North and a poor South. Because of this division, we have one of the great effects today, which is called migration, and it is not just about North Africa, the Middle East and the consequences for us in Europe, in the European Union. This is a global process. We see it in South and East Asia, we see it in America. If we do not control this situation, if we do not start to treat it economically and not only humanely, if we do not form a global coalition for cohesion policy on development, then of course we will not achieve these very important objectives.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, coherence of development policies is a fundamental principle of our policies to ensure that we support and not damage the development prospects of the poorest countries. It will be crucial, above all, for the success of the Sustainable Development Agenda and for determining its progress. The European Union and its Member States are grappling with a migration crisis that they still cannot manage. Yet they do not realise that, if we want to tackle the root causes of flows, there is a great deal to be done to ensure the coherence of our foreign, development, trade and fiscal policies, because global inequalities are currently swirling. Every year, developing countries lose hundreds of millions of euros, which would be essential for providing basic services to their citizens, with the tax avoidance and evasion of our companies. Coherence of development policies therefore means making country-by-country reporting compulsory for multinationals, as well as carrying out an in-depth analysis of the effects of European fiscal policies on developing countries, starting with the tax treaties that we conclude with them.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The requirement of coherence is one of the important principles of policy in the European Union, which is confirmed in all versions of the EU Treaties. Very early on, already in the Maastricht and Amsterdam Treaty texts, policy coherence was codified in the interests of development. It then took until 2005 for the European Union to agree on a European consensus on development policy. However, we still have to note that there are still shortcomings in the coordination of individual policies between the Member States and the EU institutions. This report also expresses this. A consistent coordinated policy approach in the EU is more urgent than ever on our doorstep, given developments in our globalised world and the problems, not least in the countries in need of development. Today, development policy can no longer be just a crisis policy or individual measures to combat hunger in the world. Foreign policy, agricultural measures, food security, fisheries policy, economic policy, financial policy, health, not least security policy, are policy areas that are inseparable in development cooperation. That is why we must now turn the texts and words into action, in cooperation between the EU institutions and the Member States, but also in the cooperation of the various areas of the Commission, and last but not least, here in the European Parliament, we must also look at the fact that we are also making greater use of policy coherence in development cooperation between our own committees. We, too, still have some catching up to do.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, without genuine coherence in development policies, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development will only be on paper. And trade policy is one of the decisive areas for testing this policy coherence. Trade agreements, which the Union is negotiating all over the world, need to be aligned with the new sustainable development goals and include strong chapters on sustainable development. The Commission must also fulfil its promise to study the potential impacts on developing countries before concluding any agreement. And it is necessary to present to this Parliament a report on trade aid granted to developing countries. What I ask the Commission is whether it can assure us that these concerns are already being taken into account in the Union's trade negotiations, including the most important ones, the TTIP with the United States of America and the trade agreement with Japan.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I, too, would like to call for a new deal, i.e. the slogan of the new deal, because, in my opinion, we are on the cusp of a period when global wealth should also be directed towards the poorest countries today. We need to look the so-called truth in the eye, and I very much appreciate the report because it describes all the crisis areas, whether it is migration, whether it is trade and finance, food security or health, climate change or security, all of which, in my opinion, are very truthfully described in the report. From my point of view, it is important that policy coherence be linked to the Member States of the European Union, i.e. that we do not leave out national parliaments and, in general, the Member States and their citizens. It is important to involve not only the efficiency aspect in this process, but also communication with those Member States that have already been discussed here. I must point out that the report also mentions the author, Mr Preda, of the impact of the European Union's policies, which we should examine precisely in the fields of agriculture, trade and energy. It also explicitly highlights the issue of biofuels. I have to rebuy the Czech Government here to some extent, because that is precisely the aspect of how biofuels are taken into account and what their experience is not only in agriculture, but also in other sectors, so in this, for example, the Czech Government is clearly failing, it has chosen the least demanding way to meet the criteria set by the European Union. And there are a number of other areas in this report, which is why I believe that the report is of good quality, and I am very happy to support it in the next vote.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, to say that in 2015 twelve areas were defined as priorities by the European Union for development, ranging from trade to migration, from health to gender issues. Unfortunately, education and culture are not contemplated, which says a lot about our goals. The truth is that our attention has been focused on banking, finance, the Troikas of this world and little has been looked at what is the beginning and the end of Europe: people. There is a legal responsibility for the impact of European policies on developing countries. However, we have not been able to correct incoherent policies that eradicate, for example, poverty in the world. On the European pier, austerity increased the number of poor and unemployed. The coherence of these policies must be a coordinated and sustained political commitment internally and externally, but there are so many inconsistencies! For example, agricultural protectionism, which leaves Africa in hand to itself, in trade, in migration, in finance with illicit capital flight.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague, Cristian Preda, on his excellent report.  As we have just adopted the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals, are preparing to revise the Cotonou agreement and the European Union is experiencing an unprecedented migration crisis, it is more crucial than ever to redouble efforts to ensure that policy coherence for development becomes a real mode of action and delivers results beyond the concept stage. I would like to focus on four things. First, the coherence of development policies must contribute to the establishment of the rule of law, democracy and good governance in developing countries, in order to serve the goal and ambition of sustainable results. Without stable democratic states, development assistance irrigates plants without root and therefore unable to produce fruit. Secondly, I would like to underline the key role of the national parliaments and the European Parliament, on the one hand, and the Union delegations, on the other, in ensuring a coherence not only horizontal but also vertical of policies. This role needs to be strengthened, particularly in the policy-making of parliaments and the implementation by delegations.  Third, ownership is a key issue. In reality, the CPD is to ensure that, in the medium term, every directorate-general, every ministry, every region, every embassy or delegation embraces the objectives of European development policy. Efforts must continue in this direction.  Fourth and final point, I support the rapporteur's idea of a European summit dedicated to policy coherence for development. This should enable concrete recommendations and a renewal of the commitment for the CPD, such as a genuine modus vivendi and operandi in all external dimensions of the Union's action. In conclusion, Mr President, let us not forget that the coherence of policies in the service of development is essential to protect the Union's capacity for action, credibility and budgetary effectiveness. In this sense, I believe that the momentum that was started in 2015 through the European Year for Development to better integrate European citizens into this policy and these debates must continue to be maintained.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, as many colleagues mentioned, today around 1.5 billion people in the world are living in poverty with severe deprivation in health, education and living standards. Most of them are women.  Policy coherence for development is an important part of the 2030 agenda and should indeed be made an integral part of the EU’s foreign policy, as well as a legally binding set of principles for our Member States to follow.
