We know that the EU is a major – and of course the largest – provider of humanitarian financial expert assistance to the developing countries, but the current migration crisis, and many more like it in other regions, have severely worsened the already drastic situation for hundreds of millions of people. Environmental issues such as desertification only make things worse. The intensification of assistance towards guaranteeing food security and the development of the private sector in developing countries, as well as introducing binding rules, will help us.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European This report points to a number of long-standing shortcomings in institutional interpolitical coordination in the wider areas of development policy. While noting that development policy coherence as a European concept was born long before the refugee crisis, it should be seen that, in the current situation, the creation of close consistency between development and migration policy has become an existential issue for the effective functioning of the Union. I would add to this the urgent involvement of the common foreign and security policy in improving coherence. Indeed, the European External Action Service must now make stabilising the EU's neighbourhood a priority, putting Community development goals and instruments at the service of managing and preventing the refugee wave. And let me draw particular attention here: when we talk about refugees, pay particular attention to children.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Commissioner, it seems essential to me that the priorities and policies of countries and regions be taken into account when drawing up the European Union's strategy for development. We cannot take paternalistic positions in which we define the models with which third countries should be governed. It is essential not to torpedo the creation and emergence of endogenous production capacities. It is important to ensure that developing countries are not strongholds of the dumping of products produced by our economies, such as industrial excesses resulting from ultra-liberal policies inserted in our markets, where milk is just one example. On the other hand, I call for firm action by all to comply with the recent climate agreement reached at COP 21. I would like to say that the acidification of the oceans calls into question the food security of all humanity. The main responsible for reversing this situation are the so-called "developed" countries where we are included.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, nowadays it is more than obvious that a coherent development policy is needed in order to successfully tackle the most urgent social problems across the globe and, what is more, to achieve peaceful, just and inclusive societies. The challenges of the past years have already shown us that building synergies between different EU policies leads to improved results. However, a coherent policy management also demands a global framework which can deal with the complexity of the task, to ensure coherence between many factors: global goals and national contexts; international agendas and processes; and between economic, social and environmental policies. The EU and its global partners have to constantly support an approach based on collaboration, mutual accountability and human rights, in order to ensure that economic, environmental and social progress will be sustainable.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, coherence of development policies is a key element in achieving the objectives of the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. This strategy, although provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon, has not been implemented at the moment. There is still no shared interpretation of the coherence of development policies. A human rights-based approach would make it possible to better understand the coherence of development policies, because if the obstacles to achieving rights are not tackled, there can be no progress towards sustainable development and the eradication of poverty. Impact assessments are the main instrument for achieving policy coherence for development. The European Union must invest more resources to analyse policy coherence. At the moment, there are few studies and they do not deal appropriately with the potential impact on developing countries. These analyses should aim at identifying inconsistencies and develop appropriate mechanisms for monitoring and monitoring progress in the coherence of development policies, including proposals on how to overcome inconsistencies between policies.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, we have not made sufficient progress in overcoming development policy inconsistencies because, among others, neither the Lisbon Treaty nor the Busan Forum on Aid Effectiveness nor the Millennium Declaration has been implemented in a concrete way. Commissioner, we need political will, involvement and, as you acknowledge, institutional collaboration. Institutional collaboration does, but without forgetting the fundamental role of local and regional administrations.  Last April, the Basque Governing Council approved a framework of reference for the coherence of development policies in the Basque Country to move towards more humane and sustainable development and to address current challenges at the domestic and international level. Commissioner, what role will it play in political dialogue for local and regional administrations? Do you know the commitment and agreement of the Basque Country? Do you think it could be a good practice for Europe?

name: João FERREIRA
text: – (2) Mr President, discussing the coherence of development policies requires assessing the extent to which the European Union's sectoral policies contribute to the objectives it says to pursue in the field of development aid, in particular the fight against poverty. This inevitably leads us to note that, if this is a serious and rigorous exercise, many of these policies not only do not contribute but also contradict the good intentions proclaimed. What can we say about the disastrous effects of the deregulation and liberalisation of international trade that the European Union still wants to impose, in particular through the so-called "economic partnership agreements"? What about the deregulation of the financial system of tax havens that deprives developing countries of huge revenues? What about the inhumanity of migration and asylum policies?  All this without forgetting the attempt to export and impose models of economic and political organisation that most often disrespect the sovereignty, needs and legitimate choices of developing countries. The infernal cycle of impoverishment, dependence and subordination of these countries has very concrete causes, inseparable from the nature of capitalism, which these reports rarely face head-on.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I was glad to get here in time for catch-the-eye. I did mean to speak on this earlier but I got held up with the trains. I have just come back from the debate in the UK where we have been talking about potential Brexit, and one of the things under discussion was whether or not the UK is subject to ‘closer union’. All countries need to have development policy, of course, but when you have policies for coherence of development within the EU, it is quite clear that this is just one of the many areas where, despite the words of Mr Cameron and his crew of EU fanatics, if you are in the EU then of course you are going to be subject to closer cohesion on a whole range of policies , and to ever-closer union. Whether or not the words are said does not matter: you are subject to it. So, as with so many of the things that Mr Cameron says, I will be warning people that when he says one thing he actually means another.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, there is nothing more incoherent than the prospect of Britain withdrawing from the European Union and starting to compete with other aid donors in a way which would be wasteful and counter-productive. The British influence in European development efforts has helped leverage greater commitment to the UN 0.7% GNP aid target, to untying aid, and now to mainstreaming the UN Sustainable Development Goals. In my own East of England constituency, I am proud to represent the Fair Trade organisation Banana Link in Norwich, a development education centre in Colchester, and to support students from developing countries through the Cambridge Trust. Development groups like Global Justice UK in Watford rightly question us about the development impact of TTIP. Those in Britain who support international development recognise that we live on a common planet, they recognise the importance of international cooperation and see the advantages of working together. They see it not as a choice between working together in Europe and in the wider world, but of both being mutually reinforcing. The case for international development is for Britain to remain in the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – (Speakers are not heard) to be fully aware that the migrant crisis will certainly not stop. The migrant crisis will only significantly intensify and create added difficulties if our global policy and coherent policy in what it means to help develop is not effective enough in terms of synergy effects. Namely, synergy, european union policy, synergy of member states' policies, but also synergies between those regions, large but also small towns wishing to participate in development, this is what the Commission must do.  I also have a number of private companies, small and large, that want to participate in the renovation and not with some hidden ambitions and hidden goals, but honestly. So, I call on the Commission to be at the forefront of these synergies so that we can actually achieve development.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this engaging debate. I have taken careful note of your remarks and I am grateful for the help in our reflections on the way ahead. Let me take a couple of specific points which were mentioned in the report and which were brought up during the debate. First of all, we all agree that the coherence of all European Union policies is a key issue and is enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty. You mentioned important issues relating to tax evasion and tax avoidance, tax loopholes and tax havens. All these things are, of course, very important today and we must address those challenges. The refugee problem was also mentioned, as well as issues related to human rights. There were also questions about TTIP and about our treaties with Japan. The European Union takes into account sustainable development in its trade agreements. First, impact assessments are carried out. Second, chapters on sustainable development are part of the agreements. All trade agreements are decided on according to well—established rules involving the European Parliament. I agree that ensuring effective coordination in our daily work and placing policy coherence for development within the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development are key. We stand ready to work closely with Parliament in this direction, in the context of the ongoing revision of the European Consensus on Development. Our shared ambition is to make policy coherence for development a standard element in policymaking across sectors. In key thematic areas, such as trade, immigration or climate action, we simply cannot afford to do business as usual. We need smart policies geared towards positive development impacts.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – The report rightly makes important points to highlight the problems of developing countries. It is a fact that 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty and experiencing deprivations in terms of health, standard of living, education. The majority are women. We believe that the Coherence of EU Development Policy is a key element in the implementation of the new Agenda for Sustainable Development. It is recalled that the sustainable development objectives apply to both developing and developed countries and must be fully integrated into the EU's decision-making process, both at home and abroad. It is noted that some States have established an effective interministerial coordination mechanism with a specific mandate for sustainable development policy coherence. It is right that Member States monitor and exchange good practices adopted by other States.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. – It is important to build sustainable development through coordinated policies for development at global level. The 2015 PCD resolution analyses seven priority areas: migration, trade and finance, food security, health, climate change, gender and security. The European Council meeting on PCD would also be crucial for defining the responsibility of individual EU institutions in achieving commitments in this area. When we talk about the sustainable development goals, we should involve third countries more intensively in the EU decision-making process. PcD is a key element in the implementation and achievement of the new Sustainable Development Agenda.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of Commissioner Arias Cañete, let me first thank honourable Members for their questions on the Commission’s action on nuclear installations in Belarus. Allow me to update you on how we are working towards ensuring the facility will be operated only with the highest level of safety standards. Nuclear safety remains a key priority for the Commission as confirmed by the Energy Union Framework Strategy.  While fostering cooperation, transparency and trust, we are using all the instruments at our disposal to ensure the highest possible safety standards in the EU and internationally. This is absolutely non-negotiable. On EU-Belarus nuclear safety cooperation: that is exactly the approach we have always taken with Belarus – nuclear safety and radiological protection have always been the key focus of our exchanges.  Since 2011, the European Union has been providing the Belarusian nuclear regulatory authority with technical assistance under the EU’s Instrument for Nuclear Safety cooperation by transferring EU best practices on the regulatory process, including formulation of licensing conditions and inspection practices, from site selection to commissioning and operation. Since April 2015, one EU expert has been based in Minsk, where we have been strengthening the regulator during the construction of the nuclear plant project from an early stage. The ultimate aim is to share EU expertise and build national capacity to ensure compliance with the best international practices and standards.  Through this technical assistance the competent regulatory authority of Belarus has improved its human and technical capacity. However, the Commission considers that the independence of the Belarusian regulator has to be further strengthened and a close monitoring of development is therefore needed.  On nuclear safety stress tests: as I said before, openness and transparency is essential when it comes to nuclear safety. By working together with our neighbours in an open way we can benefit from the exchange of information and expertise while building trust. In that spirit, the Commission welcomes Belarus’s extensive use of IAEA expert peer review services to help ensure safety.  Before I address where we are with the Ostrovets nuclear safety stress test, I would like to clarify two things which are essential in understanding the overall process.  Firstly, nuclear safety stress tests, both in the EU and in third countries, are carried out on a voluntary basis. Legally speaking, the European Union cannot oblige any Member State, nor third countries, which choose nuclear energy, to undertake such stress tests. Nevertheless, there is a political commitment to perform stress tests within the EU and an encouragement to extend them outside, as the March 2011 European Council called not only for comprehensive and transparent risk and safety assessments of all EU nuclear power plants, but also for carrying out similar stress tests in the neighbouring countries and worldwide. Since then, the Commission has been promoting the undertaking of stress tests in neighbouring countries. It is encouraging that Ukraine has already voluntarily participated in such an exercise and Armenia is currently in the process of doing so, supported financially by the European Union.  Secondly, a stress test is a national competence. It is performed by the operator and supervised by the national nuclear regulatory authority. It is only after the national stress test assessment is finalised and the outcome of the assessment is reported on, that the Commission can and in fact does organise peer reviews by EU national nuclear safety authorities. In June 2011, based on a Commission initiative, several neighbouring countries, including Belarus, confirmed their willingness to undertake nuclear stress tests by signing the Declaration on conducting nuclear safety stress tests.  Since then, we have been urging Belarus to perform a nuclear safety stress test. The Commission expects, in the light of the Council conclusions in February 2016, that EU-Belarus cooperation will evolve positively also in this regard.  What are the next steps? The Commission was informed by Belarus that it has now put in place a legal instrument regulating the implementation of nuclear safety stress tests in line with European specifications. Belarus has also indicated that upon conclusion of the Ostrovets stress test process, the national assessment report will be presented to the Commission in the course of 2016 and 2017.  On our side, the necessary preparations for the peer review have already been done, and it is now in the work programme of the European Nuclear Safety Regulators Group. Together with the Commission, this group of experts will organise the peer review as soon as we receive the national assessment report.  While this is already a positive development, the Commission would like to speed up the process’s implementation in Belarus and to receive the stress test report as soon as possible. Therefore, our services are planning a technical mission to Belarus in the coming months to discuss progress.  To conclude, let me assure you that the Commission remains fully committed to raising nuclear safety with the Belarusian authorities at all political levels. We will continue to promote the highest level of standards on nuclear safety in Belarus, together with all of our international partners.  Let me also assure you that we are in close contact with the neighbouring Member States, in particular Lithuania, to follow the developments with the Ostrovets nuclear power plant. I will ensure that the European Parliament is kept fully up to date with all the developments as and when they happen.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Belarusian nuclear power station was first envisaged backed in the 1980s. However, due to the Chernobyl disaster in 1986 these plans were halted until less than a decade ago. Construction began in 2013 and should cost around USD 10 billion. It must be pointed out that the reactor employed, a water-water energetic reactor, is the same as is currently planned for use in the Hanhikivi nuclear power plant in Finland. The fears of the international community, especially Lithuania, are understandable. Belarus has never had a nuclear power plant on its territory, thus raising fears of inability to operate it properly. Therefore, in order to alleviate these concerns, Belarus should allow for a series of necessary stress tests performed under the auspices of the International Atomic Energy Agency, as well as a comprehensive environmental impact assessment, particularly on the matter of drinking-water sources shared with Lithuania. With EU sanctions lifted, relations between the EU and Belarus are once again moving forward. I believe, therefore, that a solution to the current issues around the Ostrovets nuclear power plant will be found soon, since, in the field of nuclear energy, there can be no other way but multilateral cooperation between all parties involved, directly or indirectly, be that Belarus, Lithuania, the EU, the Russian Federation, whose specialists are building the plant, or any other international institution concerned. I want to add that nuclear energy is also environmentally friendly, and with proper maintenance, nuclear plants can last for decades on end.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. "It was belarus that suffered the most as a result of the Chernobyl disaster. 23% of the country's land has been complained about, which is why Belarus has pursued an extremely cautious energy policy over the years, avoiding being involved in nuclear power plant projects. In 1999, it signed a memorandum on the matter. What changed this policy? – geostrategic energy games conducted within the framework of the Economic Union by the Russian Federation. The Ostrovets nuclear power plant is a joint Belarusian-Russian project with huge Russian funding, with Russian technology, with little Chinese funding. The power plant is located in areas right next to the border with Lithuania, 50 km from the capital of lithuania. It is located in areas that are seismically active, to be used to cool the water of the Wilii. In addition, there is currently an air corridor over the power plant, which will probably have to significantly change the direction of flights in that space. Why am I talking about this? I am also speaking because Belarus has not performed its obligations under the Espoo Convention and all the arguments I have mentioned have not been fully explained there. In addition, poles – my compatriots – also live in these areas and they, like belarusians and Lithuanians, protested.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Lukashenko stated in public four years ago that the Astravo nuclear power plant, the beginning of the quote , "must be the cheapest of all those that the Russians and others have built in the world", the end of the quote. I'm scared to hear that. And I think you won't be calm. It would be ridiculous to hear this if it weren't very sad. The construction of the Astravo power plant arbitrarily and by saving security is continued, in violation of the International Conventions of Espoo and Aarhus, without carrying out any mandatory stress-tests and, worst of all, stealing as usual in Soviet construction.  Illegal and unsafe construction is taking place right on the border of the European Union and fifty kilometres from Vilnius, and we are hearing the Commission's comments today, which, I apologise, Mr Commissioner, were and are insufficient. The decision to build the Astravo power plant is a political decision by Moscow. It is a decision to maintain energy influence in the region. Let's wake up before it's too late. Compromises with nuclear security are a straight road to catastrophe. After all, we have an affair with dictator Lukashenko, who is building his own nuclear state. If he didn't learn chernobyl lessons, dear gentlemen, did we teach them ourselves?  I want to remind everyone that the nuclear disaster does not recognise borders. Colleagues, the solution is only one: unsafe nuclear construction must be stopped in order for the Astravo nuclear to be considered, and a continuous critical dialogue is needed, enabling the European Commission to scrutinise and supervise these constructions in detail. A strong response from the European Union is needed for both Minsk and Moscow. The European Union must use all its bargaining power. I see no reason why, with regard to Belarus, the European Union should not adapt the experience of the model of nuclear negotiations with Iran, including the United Nations Security Council.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I am pleased to be able to speak on such an important subject as the safety of nuclear power plants, and not only in connection with the construction of a new nuclear power plant on the Belarus-Lithuanian border. According to World Nuclear Association statistics, as of 1 May 2016, 440 nuclear reactors were in operation in 30 countries and another 173 reactors are planned to be built, including in EU countries. We recently commemorated the sad anniversary of the tragic accident at Chernobyl. On this occasion, I organised a round table with the participation of Belarusian experts, as well as civil society representatives, who shared with us their experiences of this disaster.  According to their assurances, the construction of the new power plant is carried out in accordance with all the latest standards and under the supervision of NGOs. However, nuclear installations located in the territory of 'old' EU member states, such as Belgium, also raise safety concerns. And I cannot fail to mention Ukraine, where nuclear installations are located on the border of battle lines. Our views certainly differ in many ways, but we need to have a debate on how to eliminate accident risks as much as possible and ensure energy and civil safety.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Thank you for your agreement to participate in this, I believe, debate that is important for europe as a whole. Unfortunately, I am disappointed that Commissioner Cañete has not found an opportunity to answer an important question of his competence regarding the threat posed by the construction of nuclear facilities at the border of the European Union. I am even more disappointed with the Commission's response to the huge problem of the construction of the Astravo power plant, which is in breach of international environmental and nuclear safety standards. The signals sent from the Commission are formal and even misleading. I am referring, in particular, to Commissioner Cañete's previous reply to me that the 'stress' tests were carried out at the Belarusian nuclear power plant when they had not even started. The recent statement by Health Commissioner Andrew that Belarus is implementing all the necessary international conventions is also perplexed.  Meanwhile, the Arhus and Espoo Conventions organisations found Belarus to be in breach of these conventions in 2014. Belarus ignores such conclusions, but why is it closed to the Commission, which is a member of these conventions? Understand our concerns – at the border between Lithuania and the European Union, an authoritarian state is building a nuclear power plant with the hands of a Russian company very quickly, and all this is done in accordance with international standards. Especially since we know what a culture of work is and what the approach to transparency is. For example, a serious incident occurred in construction in April – part of the construction collapsed – but Minsk tried to cover up the incident. The attitude of the resin Belarus is also demonstrated by the selection of the site itself without inviting the IAEA site evaluation mission. The list of violations and opacity is long. Belarus does not answer questions about the impact on the main rivers of Lithuania, due to the resilience in the event of the plane's fall, does not prepare emergency preparedness plans, does not worry about the management of nuclear fuel waste, ignores seismological studies and so on. In addition, your report has just recognised that the Belarusian nuclear safety regulator is not independent. This means that nuclear safety does not depend on experts, but on the undemocratic state government. I therefore urge the Commission to present to the European Parliament as soon as possible a very specific threat plan that will force Belarus to comply with international safety and transparency standards. This plan should also send a clear message to Minsk that electricity generation at the expense of the power plant built at the expense of security measures intersects with the principles of fair trade, and such electricity is undesirable on the European Union market.   (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question of the person who raised the Blue Card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – This, of course, is an issue which is broader than a European Union issue; it is an international issue. You have said quite a lot about what you want the Commission to do in this case. You have also mentioned the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). I am just wondering, as you did not give any concrete suggestions, what you would like the IAEA to do on this. Can you give me any suggestions for what it could do, more than it has done already?

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: answer to the blue card question. – In fact, the situation is very difficult, because first of all the lot was chosen and then, now, it is thought to invite specialists to investigate whether the site is suitable. This is a political decision. And there are very many such solutions. And the fact that Belarus promises to do 'stress tests' but does not do them, and the Commission is also being guided by the nose, because the Commissioner said that Belarus had already done 'stress tests'. Indeed, as a member of the conventions, the Commission believes that we must raise the issue, and that safety requirements must be guaranteed, not then we will talk about when the troubles are already happening, and we will not know what to do.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the IAEA monitors nuclear energy development throughout the world under the auspices of the UN. This is a clear case of the EU building up its part. If Belarus is developing an industry that concerns its neighbours, that is a matter they should refer to the IAEA and the UN.  Obviously, Belarus, and any other country that wishes to develop a nuclear industry, should be subject to existing international rules. I personally support more nuclear power in the UK, and expect all of our developments to be subject to IAEA rules as well – just like any other country. Sovereign states should be free to develop their countries as they wish so long as they operate within accepted international law. If international law is broken it is a matter for the UN.  The EU is hungry for influence and power. Trade and economic cooperation is the excuse for the existence of the EU, not the reason. Not content with intervening in the lives of its citizens, this organisation is desperate to intervene with the policies of its neighbours. Each of you, as nation states, should support the IAEA and refrain from the temptation to intervene and interfere with the business of sovereign independent states. Use existing international law and, if it is broken, use the UN. These are the conventions that, as sovereign nations, we should all respect and we should use.  There is no requirement for the EU to build up what it does, to act as a single entity, as a quasi-superpower, as a federal state. There is no need for this. We have laws; we have bodies to enforce them. If those laws are being broken on such an important issue as nuclear power, then let us use the United Nations; let us use the existing authorities and let us ensure that our people are properly protected in the correct manner without allowing political ambitions and political manoeuvrings to interfere in any way.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, nuclear disasters are one of the worst threats to humanity. The Chernobyl accidents in 1986 and Fukushima in 2011 must be taken very seriously; That is why it is legitimate for the European Parliament to be concerned about the safety of the Ostrovets nuclear power plant, which Belarus is in the process of completing with a view to being operational in 2018.  It is indeed worrying that this plant has not been subjected to the stress test recommended by the European Parliament's resolution of 14 March 2013. However, this test is an indispensable precaution. It was carried out after Fukushima on 145 reactors within the European Union and on 20 reactors outside the EU. The 2013 resolution thus developed a culture of nuclear safety in Europe that Belarus would be well advised to respect.  This is all the more desirable since the Ostrovets power plant is located only 50 kilometres from Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania. Nuclear safety is also the subject of international cooperation organized, under the control of the International Atomic Energy Agency, by the Treaty of 17 June 1994. This international cooperation will, of course, continue within the framework of the Europe of nations, which I call for. However, legitimate concern about the safety of Ostrovets should not be used by the Union to attack Russia once again. Belarus is indeed an ally of Russia, which deployed a military airbase there in 2015, and it is no secret that Russia financed the construction of the Ostrovets power plant. I therefore ask the Union not to take advantage of this matter to further degrade our relations with Russia.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to remind the Commissioner that there are different reactors: more expensive, cheaper, safer in one way or another. I do not know what a reactor that meets the highest standards, but if the Commissioner knows what it means, only one editor in the world has the highest standards, because others have to have smaller ones. I therefore do not understand why this reactor must have the highest standards in Belarus. On the other hand, speaking of politics in general, I would like to remind you that we, and unfortunately my country, Belarus, are pushing Russia. For many years, they have consistently – and the United States and the Union – have been attacking Mr Lukashenko and thus pushing him into Russia's embrace. We've seen it ourselves. Mr Lukashenko does not want to be a client of Russia at all, he does not want Russia to be the only ally of Belarus. But it is we who, by attacking Mr Lukashenko, every time we push him – I repeat – into russia's embrace, and that is what I would like to draw attention to.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Commissioner, we have just pointed out the 30th anniversary of the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl, belarus. And that is why the construction of a new plant in the same territory, this time in Ostrovets, wakes up ghosts and raises fears. And as we saw in Chernobyl and Fukushima, nuclear disasters are devastating, they don't respect borders, space, time. They kill thousands of people and irreversibly injure the planet. On this new plant the Commission has ensured that the whole security process is following and that European citizens have no reason to fear. Believe. We have to believe it! But I cannot fail to remind you that the Commission which says this is the same Commission which is unable to deal with the problem of the 66% nuclear power plants that are already operating on European territory beyond their reference lifespan. The Nuclear Indicative Programme published two months ago is very clear: to comply with the Euratom Directive it takes EUR 330 billion to close and modernise nuclear power plants and only one third of that amount is provisioned. People protest but the Commission washes their hands.  I recently addressed several questions to Commissioner Arias Cañete about the safety of the Almaraz nuclear power plant in Spain, near the Portuguese border. In his reply the Commissioner informed me that the Commission is awaiting notification of the transposition of the measures of the new Directive. Until then, spanish legislation works, it is the one who has the license that ensures that everything works well. In other words, in a central company operating beyond the deadline, where there have been repeated ly operating failures, the Commission has no proactive action. Wait and wait is little. Therefore, Commissioner, I believe what I said here about the safety of the new nuclear power plant to be built. I would also like to be able to believe that the Commission is doing everything it should to promote the security of these plants, of all plants within the Union. And at least in Almaraz it's not!

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We are talking here about supposedly or actually unsafe nuclear power stations. I would like to talk about safer nuclear power stations. The German Government has dealt with some contradictions with its panicked decision to shut down all nuclear power stations. First, Chancellor Merkel can be celebrated as a global climate savior, and then she dispenses with this climate-friendly technology. For years, the Nuclear Authority in Geneva has declared Germany's nuclear power plants to be among the safest in the world. Now they are switched off. First, the federal government wanted to be a pioneer, and now no one is following it. France is extending the life of its nuclear power plants by ten years and wants to build new ones. Finland, the USA and great Britain want to build new nuclear power plants. In Belgium, a power plant close to the German border, which was shut down due to Fukushima, is being reconnected to the grid. In Eastern Europe, outdated nuclear power plants are continuing to run and new ones are being built. Japan is bringing back one nuclear power plant to fukushima after another. China is now building 24 new nuclear power plants and even wants to build one in Sudan. There are 443 nuclear power plants in operation worldwide – more than before Fukushima. In addition, the German energy transition has also led to an explosion in German electricity prices. Not only is German nuclear policy highly unsolidaristic towards Germany's neighbours, it also leads to less security and higher electricity prices for the Germans. Let us now take an example to the Swedes, and let us withdraw this decision to leave the eu! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Henkel, I wanted to ask you: do you know how much of the world's energy is covered by nuclear power today? Can you really say that it contributes to climate protection? It's less than three percent. And the second question: because of the supposedly safe German nuclear power plants: what do you say, for example, about the Cases krümmel and Brunsbüttel?

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have already told you that the number of nuclear power stations in the world is increasing and that 24 new nuclear power stations are being built in China, for example– that is where the music plays. It should be clear to everyone that nuclear power does not emit CO2 when it is produced. And these incidents that you are talking about there have absolutely nothing to do with the reactors. I maintain that the German nuclear power stations are by far the safest in the world.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Belarus' first two nuclear power stations are currently being carried out, and these reactors are being built with the support of Russia, the Russian company, even though they will build the nuclear power plant in its entirety. In addition, Russia will invest the equivalent of SEK 1.5 billion in the first phase of construction of the plant. All this comes at a time when Belarus is already very dependent on Russia. 90% of Belarus' energy imports come from a single importer, namely Russia. Once again, we are seeing Russia trying to use energy as a weapon to influence other countries in the direction that suits the Kremlin. This has happened before, in Armenia, in Kyrgyzstan, in Kazakhstan, in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Ukraine, Georgia – and it will happen again tomorrow – in Belarus. That is why the European Parliament must examine this project. Firstly, because the project naturally has a huge environmental impact on other countries, then also because the project is not in line with the EU's objective of diversifying Europe's energy sources. The Commission must stop pretending to be nothing and consider the geostrategic consequences of such a project.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Mr President, the chernobyl tragedy directly affected more than two million Belarusians and indirectly the entire planet. Nuclear pollution does not understand borders, it affects everyone and that is why we must have this debate. We do not seem to learn from our mistakes anywhere, when Belarus is building a new nuclear power plant without carrying out the resistance tests envisaged with the European Commission or the necessary impact assessments. The Commission would do well to invite Belarus not to go down a path whose risks it already knows and has already suffered, but must above all contribute to a radical change in the energy model here in the European Union. Half of the world's nuclear energy is produced in Europe. We have enough technology and resources to change this model, and also examples like Germany's, which is already doing so. It is time for other countries to do so too and for the Commission to push Member States on this path. Let's start by giving an example. Let us begin by dismantling the power plants that have already exceeded their lifetime and are a potential danger, such as Garoña and Almaraz in Spain, and which pose a potential danger to our lives and to Earth.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: – Mr President, we have heard a lot of important points and concerns regarding the Belarusian nuclear power plant (NPP) project, but I would like to turn your attention to the fact that, while we are worrying because of an NPP construction close to the EU’s borders, there is also something to be worried about within the borders of the EU.  In Hungary, my state, two new Russian—type blocks are going to be built in the next couple of years. This is just the same construction and the same technology as in Ostrovets, Belarus: the Russian—type VVER 1200 reactors. This Member State, Hungary, has already proved that it understands EU law in quite a ‘flexible’ way when it comes to nuclear projects. Regarding this nuclear project in Hungary, there was a veto from the Euratom Supply Agency because the contract with Russia was not in line with EU law. There is an ongoing infringement because of the lack of tendering, according to European public procurement law. There is an in-depth investigation because of non—tendering. There is an in-depth investigation because of possible forbidden state aid regarding the same project. That was a concluded pilot project because of the lack of transparency of the project. This Member State intentionally violated the EU regulation regarding nuclear waste with unlawfully shipped nuclear waste from a former serious incident in the existing NPP to Russia in 2014. Would you buy a used car from those guys? And do you think that it is a good idea to let it go when they plan to build a new Russian nuclear power plant in the heart of Europe?   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question asked by raising the blue card – Thank you, Dear Mr. Advocate. In 96th year, Croatia signed the so-called ESPO Convention, i.e. joined the ESPO Convention, and I am saying this because you have just now presented known details about what is happening in Hungary and how this new nuclear power plant with Russian technology is being built.  Do you think Croatia should be fully engaged and participate in all these decisions as a neighbouring country and moreover do you think that the European Union should have a common policy when we talk about nuclear energy as a future strategy?

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for your question. I completely agree that we need strong cooperation between the Member States. Regarding this project, ten EU Member States participated in the process under the Espoo Convention. Still, I believe that there is not enough attention from the Member States. Mainly Austria and Germany expressed deep interest and concerns regarding the project, but I would like to ask the Member States, including Croatia, to be more active regarding this project. In small countries like Hungary, nuclear investments are not single Member State issues.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, nuclear energy is a safe form of energy, but serious security measures must be taken to use it even for peaceful purposes. Particular attention should be paid when nuclear power stations or other installations are installed near the border with the European Union. One such case is the case of the nuclear reactor in Astraviez, Belarus, for which there are reservations as to whether and to what extent it has been built in accordance with the high safety standards applicable in the European Union. This case also brings to the surface the security to be met by the nuclear installations that Albania, Skopje and Turkey intend to build in their countries. Turkey in particular is a country dangerous for causing a nuclear accident, because, like Belarus, it does not have transparent nuclear safety stress tests and on the other hand it is also a seismic country. That is why the European Union must act to ensure that both the Astraviet nuclear reactor and those to be built in the countries I have mentioned must operate in accordance with the safety standards in force in the European Union.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I must say I am very sad that Mr Etheridge has left the debating chamber and shown absolutely no interest in this serious debate. He shows himself up to be extremely ignorant, suggesting that we should all rely only on UN international laws to keep us safe. Does he not know that the most powerful nation in the world, the USA, does not endorse the UN's International Court of Justice? So where would that leave us, Mr Etheridge? I thank goodness for the vigilance of the EU. I am very glad that Parliament has decided to debate the safety of nuclear plants in Belarus. Belarus must certainly carry out all the environmental impact assessments and stress tests required by international agreements, and reassure all of its neighbours that the wider environment and citizens across the region and beyond are safe - and that includes me and Mr Etheridge. There is, however, a broader point at hand. Nuclear power carries with it risks and potential costs that are hard to assess and estimate. The humanitarian and environmental catastrophe that would occur in the case of a serious accident is terrible to contemplate, and I have seen first-hand the devastated lives of the Fukushima survivors - bereaved, bereft, suffering mental health problems, and in the case of many children unable even to play outdoors for fear of contamination.  So since being elected I have worked together with Nuclear Transparency Watch, a network founded, after a call by this very European Parliament for greater nuclear security following the Fukushima disaster in 2011. I would like to emphasise that we must continuously strive for greater nuclear safety and transparency and support the civil society organisations who work in the field to advance that transparency. The nuclear power industry is a big player in the energy industry, with huge subsidies from the public purse. It therefore has a duty to work closely with host communities and Nuclear Transparency Watch to ensure that the plants are operating to the highest standards.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, nuclear disasters bring death, bring many sick generations after them, destroy the environment and interrupt life. Basically, we all remember what it was like after the Chernobyl disaster. It's "before catastrophe" and "after catastrophe." That is why it is our job, the European Union's, when a nuclear power plant is built without respecting deadlines and perhaps with certain intentions relating to our safety. We are talking today about the Ostroveț plant in Belarus, built by the Russians for Belarus and which is only fifty kilometres from the lithuanian capital. Belarus argues that it is a good thing, that it will help it economically and help it reduce its dependence on Russia. That's not true. It's a lie. Belarus is heavily dependent on Russia, 90% of the gas comes from Russia and the plant is built by Russian companies with Russian funding. It's about $22 billion. Lithuania rightly accuses Belarus of not informing it of the construction of this nuclear power plant, of not completing an environmental impact study, of not informing citizens of the influence on drinking water and many other things. For example, we learn about this ostrovet plant only from places other than the Belarusian authorities, and it is not normal. It can also come the turn of other states. We hear that the same thing is happening in Hungary. Also with Russian funding. As such, we must be keen on the safety of ourselves, European citizens and non-Europeans.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! What we are discussing about Belarus is not a technical problem. At its core, it is a question of the political challenge of balancing legitimate interests on the basis of agreed international standards, specifically the ESPOO Convention of the Kiev Additional Protocol on Binding Strategic Environmental Assessment, everywhere. Following the notification of the planned construction of a new nuclear power plant in 2009, Belarus has formally taken into account the notification and consultation obligations. If the final location decision did not take sufficient account of the results, the EU should also be required to do so. But does your statement today confirm whether you see this political issue as yours at all? So far, the Commission has remained silent on the analogous process, despite demand in Ukraine. There, the duration of existing reactors will simply be extended until 2030 in violation of international law, although the majority of them are already shut down under EU rules. I therefore call on you to fix this construction site in principle! This includes the fact that the Kiev Protocol of 9 EU Member States has still not been ratified 13 years after its signature. At least two of these EU countries operate more than 70 reactors and plan to build four more.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Ostrowets nuclear power plant, which is currently being built in Belarus, is in breach of several international treaties: for example, the Aarhus Convention, for example, the obligation to carry out a stress test. Would you buy a car that is not tested? I would just like to mention here that the planned type WWER-1200 does not inherently provide the safety that we expect, because the ratio of length to diameter of the reactor pressure vessel is very unfavourable, making it difficult to regulate the reactor. But that is not the only problem. As has already been said here, Belarus does not have the financial resources to draw all the consequences from the operation of nuclear power in terms of safety, in terms of safety retrofits, which will certainly be necessary, including nuclear waste. Can you, Commissioner, guarantee us that the European taxpayer will not have to pay for what Belarus is not doing again?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Only a few weeks ago, on 26 April, we commemorated the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, which, after Ukraine and among many other European countries, was the largest casualty of belarus' population, with an impact to this day. This fact alone shows that this is a European matter, as it is a cross-border threat in the event of trouble. It is in our common interest for the European Union, looking beyond serious political differences, to care about improving nuclear safety in Belarus. I would add that, in the case of this country, which is 1,000 strands vulnerable to Putin's power games, this issue is not indifferent to the common EU foreign and security policy, since the energy component has long been a key element of Minsk's dependence on Moscow.  As we try to drag Belarus into the 21st century together in terms of energy dependency and nuclear security, we must find within the Union that the government of one Member State, unfortunately my country, Hungary, is taking its country back to 20th-century conditions with the Treaty of Paks II. For many decades, it has been at the mercy of Moscow, both energetically and financially. As a Hungarian Member, it is therefore my duty to draw the attention of the Commission and the European Parliament to our item on our agenda: this is also a common European matter and a danger, because it is a Member State, which, moreover, completely ignores what the Commission has put before us in the framework of the Energy Union and has received convincing support in this Parliament.  Finally, let me note that each new facility, each nuclear facility, is a new wound, a dagger to the future of the Earth. The dazzling development of the last 10 years in terms of renewable energies makes any further nuclear development in the world of power plants completely unjustified.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteurs for their excellent work. This is not a general debate. This is a very specific debate. This is not the place to consider Europe's energy structure, Europe's desirable energy structure, to what extent nuclear energy is valuable. The debate concerns a very specific investment in Belarus, close to the border with the European Union, in a sensitive place for both Lithuania and Polish. I am a little surprised by the Commissioner's speech, which was excessively technical, as if this issue were one of many investments that should only be subject to technical assessment. It is worth listening to the voice of those people who, when the Chernobyl disaster occurred, lived on the wrong side of the Iron Curtain, who were struggling with a communist dictatorship and know what disrespect for man is, disrespect for the environment. This investment, even in ecological terms, raises many doubts. But above all – and here I want to very much support those voices that underline the Russian factor – this is an investment financed, credited and actually co-organised by Russia. Russia submits its energy targets to political objectives. If the European Union has an Eastern Neighbourhood Policy, if the European Union aspires to keep the entire Old Continent safe, to pursue something like a foreign policy, it must not ignore the negative fact that it is an investment in line with Russia's political objectives.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will say in a nutshell. I am not interested in where Belarus will take the funds or whether it is taking funds for a nuclear power plant. I'm not interested in where he'll sell, and whether he'll sell, and for what amount of excess that energy. However, I am very interested in what will happen to the waste, whether it has an idea or whether it is under proper control. What technology will be used as a result and how safe will it actually be? I am very interested in Lithuania's attitude towards this investment, as lithuania is currently most at risk of operating this power plant.  I would like to make it clear that these elements, which are built in safety questions, must be considered crucial. These elements, which concern the economy, form a sovereign part of the policy of Belarus itself. It is important that the Commission use all possible available means, both legal and other, to ensure that this investment is properly controlled.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Belarus is one of the most developed countries in the former USSR and the Lukashenko Government's diplomatic orientation towards Moscow should not be a reason to create a negative climate on any occasion. Obviously, the risk of a nuclear accident is not limited to the borders of the States. We are well aware of this since the Chernobyl accident and obviously the Belarusian Government and all the decision-makers involved in the construction of the new nuclear power plant in Astraviez must take all necessary measures to ensure that the plant meets the safety standards of the international nuclear energy organisation. But the same must be said of Turkey, which is similarly trying to build a nuclear power plant across the Dodecanese, in a highly seismic region. There are also a number of old factories in Western Europe whose operation should be of concern to us. When are we going to discuss this issue as a whole? When will we discuss the Doel and Tihange units, which should have been out of service in Belgium by 2015?

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the safety of nuclear installations is a matter of the utmost importance, not only outside but also within the European Union. Let us not forget that about half of the Member States of the European Union have nuclear power plants on their territory. The average age of the reactors in operation is high, which puts us in the face of demands and risks that cannot be minimized.  This is the case, for example, with the Almaraz nuclear power plant in Spain, near the Portuguese border. The need to dismantle some reactors is evidence, for urgent reasons for safety and safeguarding the health of populations and the environment. These processes should not neglect the necessary maintenance and surveillance, before, during and after closure, waste treatment, storage and decontamination, environmental requalification of installations, and support for replacing the energy production capacity of dismantled plants, paying particular attention to environmental sustainability and energy efficiency.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, of course the situation in Belarus with regard to nuclear power is something which does need to be monitored at an international level and it is important – imperative even – to ensure that all safeguards are met. Just to clarify from earlier on in the debate that there is a broader point of principle which we were also making in this debate, which is to say that there are international organisations other than the European Union of which we are fully supportive. In this case, the IAEA and the United Nations play a very significant role just as, in a wider context across over policy issues, we could say that the G7, the G20, NATO, the IMF, the International Organization for Standardization, the World Trade Organization, the OECD, Interpol and so many others, are organisations that we want to be a part of – and yet in the UK the debate continues to focus on this one area of the European Union , as we are told we would be isolated if we were not in it. So there is a broader issue of principle here, as well as the specific situation in Belarus.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the construction of a nuclear power plant in Astraviet, Belarus, is of enormous importance for the energy policy of Belarus and the Union in terms of the safety and protection of the nuclear power plant and the environment. It is obvious that Belarus has every right to seek alternative forms of energy, considering that 90% of the gas it uses is imported from Russia. Of course, the voices of protest heard relate to the Belarusian agreement with the Russian company on the construction of the plant and the future waste management and to the financing of the whole project with $22 billion from Russia. I think that Belarus as a sovereign state can sign energy agreements without suggestions and prohibitions. We must be more concerned with conducting a stress test, the completeness of safety standards and the protection of the environment and especially the adjacent River Neris. In this we can assist the Belarusian authorities as well as the International Atomic Energy Agency with the European Group of Nuclear Safety Regulators.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank all Members for their interventions which show how high the stakes really are when it comes to energy safety and security. By way of wrap-up, I would like to pick up on a few of the wider issues raised during the debate, but first on the Ostrovets case.  Let me underline what I said at the start: the Commission will continue to use all the instruments at its disposal to ensure the highest possible safety standards in the EU and internationally. That is non-negotiable, as I already said. That is why our priority is now to ensure the timely implementation of Ostrovets nuclear safety stress tests in line with European specifications.  As always, the Commission will keep this House fully up to date with any developments as and when they happen. But let me be clear. Many of the solutions to the questions raised in this debate lie in the need to end energy isolation and complete Europe’s internal energy market. For Lithuania, as well as for all Baltic states, this means that we need to continue working towards their full integration into the European energy market. The good news is that we are making progress. We recently saw the start of operations for the electricity interconnections of Lithuania with Poland and Sweden. Thanks to the LitPol Link and NordBalt, the level of interconnection of the Baltic States with the rest of the European grid has substantially increased, from 4% in early 2014 to approximately 22%.  On gas, work is under way on the game-changing Gas Interconnector Poland-Lithuania. GIPL, as it is called, is the first gas interconnector between the Eastern Baltic Sea region and Continental Europe. When complete in 2019 it will end the region’s gas isolation, further diversify gas sources, routes and counterparts, and ultimately help to reduce prices for consumers. Much of this progress is thanks in large part to the Baltic Energy Market Interconnection Plan, which brings together all the Baltic states to cooperate on integrating the region into a European network. This is an example to others on what we can achieve under the Energy Union. But we must build on this progress.  Our next challenge is to ensure the synchronisation of the Baltic States and other isolated regions with the rest of the EU market. Our vision is of an Energy Union based on solidarity and trust, which speaks with one voice to our external partners and which, ultimately, provides the secure and sustainable energy Europe’s citizens need. That is why the Energy Union is a top Commission priority and why our focus is fully on implementation. We look forward to working hand in hand with the European Parliament to make it a reality.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – The Astravo nuclear power plant being built in the vicinity of Lithuania is not a security issue for the Whole Of the European Union, not in Lithuania or the Baltic region. However, it gives the impression that this has not yet been given due attention from the EU institutions. Belarus has so far not fulfilled its international commitments in the fields of environmental and nuclear safety in the development of the Astravo project. However, despite the fact that violations of international requirements have been found, the work of the Astravo nuclear power plant project continues, stress tests are not carried out and we do not yet have information on the safety of this project. Although the Commission states that it cannot force either Member States or third countries to carry out stress tests, the February 2016 European Council stressed the importance of political cooperation with Belarus to ensure adequate nuclear safety. It is very important that the Issue of Astravo is constantly on the political agenda of the Commission and the Council of Europe, in order to ensure that the nuclear power plant built just 42 km from the EU's external border does not pose a threat to the security of all of us.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. During this debate, our attention was drawn to the astrats nuclear power plant project in Belarus. It was signed by the Russian nuclear group Rosatom for the construction of two AES reactors. This project has raised questions from neighbouring countries about the safety status of this third-generation nuclear facility.  If there is one area that requires going beyond ideological positions and political ulterior motives, in favour of scientific and rational analysis, it is that of nuclear power. As a supporter of this clean and almost inexhaustible energy, I am convinced of the need not to take any risks in nuclear safety, except to see the future of this energy totally questioned should another Chernobyl-type accident occur.  It is also clear that this project has been validated by the IAEA and that the Rosatom Group has received approval to build power plants in India, China, Iran and Hungary. Finally, Finland has selected this group for the construction of its sixth reactor, which will be equipped with the same technology as in Belarus.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – The issue of nuclear safety and environmental protection of the Astravo nuclear power plant must be of concern not only to Lithuania, but also to Europe as a whole. The fact that the Astravo nuclear is being built in violation of the United Nations Espoo and Aarhus Conventions. Belarus also fails to comply with its commitment to nuclear safety stress tests in accordance with the EU methodology. The rules for the selection of the site for the power plant were clearly not followed, seismic and geological surveys were not properly carried out, and incidents at the power plant's construction site are concealed.   The EU must pay greater attention to nuclear power plants built by third countries, and the active dissemination of environmental and nuclear safety standards must become a necessary part of the EU's external energy policy. We often hear that the Commission does not have the leverage to stop the construction of the Astravo power plant. It is true that we cannot ban it, but we must exert pressure on Belarus to act transparently and to comply with its obligations. There are various instruments for this: the EU's instrument for nuclear security cooperation, which finances the strengthening of the Belarusian nuclear safety regulator, can be used. Almost 5 million euro from the EU budget has been allocated to this. Aid should not be unconditional. This requires stress tests to be carried out in accordance with EU standards and on time.  The Commission should also set the same conditions for restoring the EU-Belarus energy dialogue. The issue of nuclear safety in Astrave should also be included in the BEMEP agenda, and a jointly formed regional position would be of particular importance to Lithuania in its dealings with belarusian representatives.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the The new Alliance for Food Security in Africa was launched by the G8 countries in 2012. This large public private partnership is intended to attract investment in agriculture in sub-Saharan Africa in order to improve food security there. Ten African countries are involved. The EU is co-financing the initiative. In total, donor countries have pledged more than six billion U.S. dollars. The new alliance wants to emulate the model of the Green Revolution in Asia in the 1960s and 1970s. The limits of this approach and, in particular, the environmental risks associated with it are well known. Under the new alliance, African countries will be asked to implement legislative reforms to create a business-friendly environment for private investment in Africa's agriculture. Remarkably, smallholders were hardly involved in this process, although they were ultimately supposed to be the beneficiaries. Consequently, the new alliance has been heavily criticised by civil society, by the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the right to food, and by African small farmers themselves. Parliament's Committee on Development has dealt with the report in detail and will take up some worrying phenomena. Firstly, the type of agriculture and farming methods, secondly: transparency and governance, thirdly: legislative reforms, fourthly, the gender issue. Firstly, the nature of agriculture and farming methods: both the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Paris Climate Agreement indicate the need to develop an agricultural model that is much more resilient and can create sustainable food systems. The report calls on the governments in Africa not to support the model of business-oriented agriculture based on large farms, but to invest in family farms and agro-ecology. This is because family farms – small farmers – are the main investors in African agriculture and provide more than 60% of the jobs in sub-Saharan Africa. Transparency and governance: detailed information on multilateral development initiatives such as the new alliance should be accessible. At present, there are not enough details about the investment plans of the companies. We need full transparency, robust monitoring mechanisms and performance indicators, adequate institutional and legal frameworks, prior consultations with the many stakeholders and stakeholders, and a complaints mechanism for local people and communities. All participating countries must effectively implement the relevant international standards to ensure that investments respect all human rights. Business-friendly legislation: As mentioned, african countries involved are invited to implement certain business-friendly legislation, including in the area of land and seeds. Although there are various forms of land use and ownership rights in Africa, the corporate frameworks only consider the identification of land holdings when safeguarding the rights of use and ownership. The new study by the DROI Committee confirms that human rights violations have occurred under the new alliance in land transactions involving European companies and donor institutions. This is totally unacceptable. The new alliance also calls for corporate law reforms in seed law. 90% of farmers depend on the free production and exchange of their seeds. I am very concerned that the new alliance will prevent most countries from using these informal methods. I am similarly concerned about gender issues. Only 21% of small-scale farms where women are in charge were involved, despite the fact that 50% of women run sub-Saharan Africa. To sum up, the main players in the private sector are multinationals that already have a dominant market position. In addition, there is a major market imbalance between international agricultural groups, regional and national players in the countries of Africa. There are grave doubts that the new alliance will be able to contribute to poverty reduction and food security. That is why the EU and the Member States should carefully consider whether their participation in this initiative is effective at all or whether we are instead investing better together in sustainable agricultural models, as decided in the sustainable development goals. I thank the shadow rapporteurs and the AGRI Committee for Good Cooperation.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The new Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa is an extremely important initiative that aims to strengthen food security in Africa, which in turn could save millions of lives. As the European Parliament, we should make every effort to seize the opportunities contained in this programme. From my perspective, one of them is the issue of support – as Maria Heubuch has already mentioned – for small and medium-sized farmers, farms and food producers. The experience of providing development aid to Africa shows that we should not, we must not neglect the local dimension of this aid. In this case, support for family farming also has a positive impact on the well-being of the population. Aid to individual farmers and family farms would improve the economic situation of the local population.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – (For technical reasons, the speaker has to interrupt the speech and then the President asks him to go back to the beginning) Mr President, Commissioner, we must behave reciprocity in terms of environmental and social requirements with regard to agri-industrial investments made in third countries. The objectives we have set in terms of development policy should be the driving lines and local communities should continue to be available and decide on the options for future progress. With regard to natural resources it is imperative to defend the property and preservation of heritage for the benefit of the populations that depend on them. This should be possible within a well-defined regulatory framework that provides real possibilities to local communities and under the aegis of the right to food, nutrition, property and participation. These are basic and elementary rights that should not yet be claimed in our day. Because we enjoy progress in Europe at the material and political levels, we have an obligation to promote more and better progress in other parts of the world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the way in which the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition in Africa operates, which is a public-private partnership to support Sub-Saharan Africa and tackle poverty, reminds me a little of the troika in Greece. In other words, it wants to impose legislation on all the Member States involved, it wants to change the conditions for land ownership, it also wants to put conditions on the way seeds are used.  I therefore see an intervention in the internal affairs of the Member States and I wonder whether there will really be substantial assistance. We also see support for big business, we do not see support for small communities, land workers, while the agricultural investments being promoted are export-oriented and not so much to stimulate the local economy. I therefore believe that this situation cannot reverse the problems in Africa. Only the debt write-off of African states can really give them the opportunity for growth.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I have no doubt that the new Food and Nutrition And Nutrition Safety Alliance in Africa, when it was established in 2012, had excellent intentions.  What we need to keep an eye on is not turning our good intentions into something that can become a kind of neococonialism. Namely, there is no doubt that there are very big interests at stake here, and I would like primarily the interests at play to be the interests of the citizens of Africa, i.e. small family farmers in Africa, to have the right to land, to have ownership of the land, to make sure that after all we do not all use the same seeds in agriculture in this world.  Let's keep biodiversity, what we can keep from the beauty of agriculture that exists in Africa and develop that agriculture on those parameters on which we have successfully developed European agriculture.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, we are dealing with an initiative involving the G8, several multinationals, public-private partnerships through which, they assure us, millions of people can be lifted out of poverty and hunger in Africa. The dislike of the promoters does not hide what they see: accelerating the flow of private capital. The alleged charity of multinationals requires political changes that facilitate their business, because after all that is what this is about, business as usual. This initiative assumes, by verifying, because wrong, that more production through investment from large private corporations will solve the problem of hunger and malnutrition in Africa.  Now these corporations produce for profitable markets, not for the poor and hungry. This initiative will be a useful way to facilitate access to land and agricultural insums to these corporations, encouraging the change of agricultural practices in the interests of multinationals, favoring intensive export production models, with high incorporation of agrochemicals and GMOs. The big question is, who will pay your profits?

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, I thank Maria and her colleagues in the Committee on Development for this report, which is a prime example of the EU standing up to big business. I also thank the hundreds of constituents who emailed me with their concerns about the outdated model of agricultural development promoted by the G7’s so—called New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. In such an initiative, nutrition should be the logical starting point, but this is not so. Instead, nutrition comes second to opportunities for industrial agribusinesses with no focus on healthy food but rather on agricultural commodities, which of course require monocultures. This increases input dependency and land degradation. Crucially, this Parliament report argues that the new alliance must allow farmers to avoid input dependency. There will not be food sovereignty if farmers are beholden to corporations for their seeds and then brought into vicious circles of pesticide and fertilizer use. We should support farmers’ seed systems which maintain agro—biodiversity.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, I would like to commend the rapporteur for a lot of what she says about the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. There are a lot of positives in this report, and specifically comments about things which could be improved within the NAFSN.  I would like to draw out three points. Firstly, I agree completely with Notis Marias that there must be no interference with sovereignty of developing nations. Secondly, I share the concerns with regard to big multinationals playing too great a role in planning agricultural development and therefore the impact that has on smaller farmers and their right to have a say.  Thirdly, I would just take issue with the comment that the EU and its Member States are the biggest giver of aid. Well, if you take 28 countries and put all of those numbers together then of course it is going to be bigger than any one individual.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European There is a real danger that the programmes contained in this document will sink into the swamp of local and government corruption and land speculation. I believe that reinforced guarantees and monitoring are needed. Obviously, democratically elected parliaments, such as the European Parliament, must play a major role in control, which I strongly propose.  In addition, many, many programmes focus on the security of food supply. Nevertheless, I believe that priority support for production and funding structures for children's food should come first. As part of our focus on combating child hunger and malnutrition, I think we should start thinking about the type of thinking that food should not be taxed anywhere.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
