text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to welcome the European Parliament’s report on the New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition and of course to thank you and congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Heubuch, for steering its preparation. It is in line with what the Commission wants to achieve under the New Alliance. Together with our partners – African governments, the African Union Commission, the private sector and G7 members – the European Union has made a commitment to promoting inclusive and sustainable agriculture-based growth. The agricultural sector in low-income countries has suffered from under-investment for decades with considerable consequences for long-term food security while also contributing to rural poverty. The investments needed to eradicate hunger are enormous.  We thus have to work together with all partners. This is what we agreed under the 2030 Agenda and its second Sustainable Development Goal: to end hunger, achieve food security and improve nutrition and also promote sustainable agriculture. In doing so we will need to mobilise additional resources for developing countries. This is what the New Alliance is trying to do: reduce poverty and link smallholders to markets by working with the local and international private sector. The European Union has been supporting the New Alliance since its launch in 2012 and has since committed EUR 1.2 billion in ten new alliance countries. This represents a powerful initiative to reduce rural poverty. Food and nutrition security in our developing partner countries is a priority area for the Commission. We want to contribute to job creation, stability, growth and sustainable development. In all our programmes under the New Alliance we make sure that we are working towards this objective.  The Commission is a staunch supporter of the voluntary guidelines on tenure of land and of the principles for responsible investment in agriculture and food systems. Within the New Alliance we have developed guidance for companies on due diligence and risk management for land-based investments in agriculture. Gender is also a prominent component in the New Alliance. Fifty-one per cent of the jobs created in 2014 benefited women. At the same time, the Commission will continue to insist on a much more targeted focus on women farmers and entrepreneurs and on actions to ensure they have equal access to land and other economic resources. Of course there are many challenges associated with our efforts and we are working hard to solve them. We are taking very seriously the concerns being voiced that the New Alliance creates a favourable environment that mainly benefits large private sector companies to the detriment of the smallholder farmers. Many of the concerns raised also here today are an integral part of the discussions with our partners in the new alliance. The European Union is very sensitive towards the smallholder farmers. They play a key role in sustainable agriculture and in combating hunger and malnutrition, and they are indeed the ones that should primarily benefit from the New Alliance actions. The European Union is also very attentive to the plight of the most vulnerable in societies who, despite the advances made, remain susceptible to crises and shocks and will continue to need our humanitarian and development assistance. We need partnerships with the private sector that encourage businesses to put sustainable development at the core of their strategies. This is particularly relevant for inclusive and sustainable agricultural development. The only option is to work together and to act responsibly, inclusively and sustainably. This also includes more involvement of farmers in civil society and the coordination of new alliance activities. The Commission will discuss and explore with all partners in the New Alliance how to better advance its implementation, also in the light of the conclusions and recommendations of this report.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank all of the shadow rapporteurs who contributed to this report on International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). It is the first time that the European Parliament presents its strategic view on the issue of IFRS. These standards are the bedrock of all investment decisions in the global capital markets, and of the evaluation of company management on behalf of its shareholders. For over a year, we have held many debates, seminars and hearings, with different stakeholders, standard setters, academics and experts. Let me focus on the main points of this report. We think that the concept of public good for the IFRS should be clarified, as well as the potential conflict between the private nature of the IASB, the standard setter, and the public good nature of the IFRS that are applied today in more than 110 countries and jurisdictions. There are differences between how we in the European Union understand the concept of true and fair view, the principles of prudence and stewardship, which are the basis of accounting standards, and the accounting setters view on this concept and principle. We insist on the need for an impact assessment for every new accounting standard or change of a current accounting standard. We think about the future of EFRAG, the private technical advisor of the European Commission in the process of IFRS endorsement in the European Union, and about the possibility on the long-term to transform EFRAG into a European agency.  We also ask for the strengthening of the role of the European Parliament, both in the process of setting accounting standards and in the endorsement process of IFRS in the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the creation of harmonised regulation on the application of high-quality accounting standards is an essential requirement for regulating competition and an effective method of removing obstacles to investment on a global scale. This correction, which is consistent with the area of prudential regulation, is all the more necessary in a period of financial crisis. The model of financial reporting principles must therefore be strengthened in order to develop a capital markets union to the point where they then inform the rules of internal governance of financial institutions. It should be stressed that, by raising the level of financial responsibility, the single market and the competitiveness of the economy have been facilitated, enabling companies to attract capital and investment. I share the rapporteur's concerns about the difficulty of the bodies responsible for establishing accounting standards for the complexity of the financial instruments used and the need for transparent and comparable global principles that can be understood by a large group of stakeholders.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, according to the European Union, the application of International Accounting Standards enables companies to attract capital and investment to international capital markets, thereby helping to strengthen the single market. Of course, the financial crisis has shown that these standards need to be reviewed. In particular, accountability should be strengthened by international financial reporting standards and the gap between investors and businesses reduced in order to protect investment. This will also enhance international comparability and thus transparency in the representation of the real situation of economic units. Furthermore, with regard to the application of International Accounting Standards in a Member State, there should be harmonisation of the institutional and legal environment as well as better information for auditors and accountants on the technical details of their implementation. Finally, transparency and credibility should be strengthened in the competent supervisory and regulatory authorities.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, let me say right from the outset that without a quality harmonisy of international accounting standards, of course there is no single or competitive European market. In this report, which of course I certainly support, I want to clearly indicate two topics. The first topic is the public and public interest that all companies listed on the stock exchange be treated equally in some way. Of course we have legislation since 2005, but I think it is in this element that the European Union must be a leader in the world financial market. And the second topic is the question of equal valuation of company prudentiality. This is also where the European Union must be the instigator so that we do not have situations where a company is bought, when a company wants to invest in a company, we do not have quality information about its creditworthness.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, international accounting standards are an important part of the European Union's regulatory and supervisory framework. These standards interact with a wide variety of EU regulatory acts on services and, in particular, in the field of prudential regulation. We follow the report on the central role of accounting standards for the development of a more transparent, community-readable market. What we do not follow is this association of the need to improve international accounting standards with the current financial crisis.  International accounting standards are important, but they cannot replace the basic measures that are required to control the world of finance, avoiding this speculation without a rule and without brakes and which leads to crises whose costs always end up being borne by them as always. In this way, let us not confuse the intervention plans. The crisis will be resolved when there is political will to take the necessary measures and which are under public control of the financial system, as well as the large oligopolies that actually have in this European Union.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Unified international accounting standards play an important role in ensuring, on the one hand, financial discipline and, on the other hand, transparency and, of course, transparency and accountability both of the private and indirect public sectors. Above all, in the implementation of accounting standards, the word trust is important. And those who argue that international accounting standards are, of course, also a partial culprit for the financial crisis and economically, can say that, of course, accounting standards are not the ones, but it is primarily the fault of those who have used them in an inappropriate manner, when, of course, accounting standards can also become the subject of abuses when they become the subject of speculation and, of course, also adjusting their balance sheets to companies. And that is why, of course, strict control over the functioning and application of these standards is needed, because only in this way can we ensure confidence.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, I think sometimes the words ‘avoidance’ and ‘evasion’ get a little lost in translation. There is certainly a spectrum from at one end, say, a plumber who uses his van for work, who decides whether it is appropriate to claim for wear and tear on a vehicle or on a mileage basis. I think few would argue that this is something we really need to stamp out of society. I think people would say it is perfectly legitimate for that plumber to choose how he goes about doing things. But then you move on to multinationals which aggressively employ teams of accountants, and I think we want to root out that kind of aggressive tax avoidance. And then of course there is evasion, which is completely breaking the law.  I think, when things get lost in translation like that, the idea of this one-size-fits-all legislation across 28 different legal systems starts to fall apart a little bit. That is the concern that I have about EU-imposed country-by-country public reporting, which could prove to be counterproductive.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The application of international financial reporting standards has made a significant contribution to strengthening the single market in the past, but the financial crisis has shown that they need to be reviewed and improved. International financial reporting standards and international accounting standards, which are essential for the efficient functioning of the internal market and capital markets, can be regarded as public good, which must ensure financial stability, sustainable development and full transparency and accountability. In short, they must serve the public interest and not just the interests of investors, lenders and creditors. They must serve the public interest.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of my dear colleague Jonathan Hill I would first of all like to congratulate Mr Stolojan on taking the initiative to present this report. I note with pleasure that we have a common understanding on many issues.  Our conclusions of the evaluation of the IAS Regulation were overall positive on the experience with IFRS and on the endorsement process, with practical improvements identified. We will carefully consider all the recommendations listed in the report. In fact we have been working on some of them already for some time. In particular, we have noted the need for a better coordination between all actors in the endorsement process. We, therefore, welcome the set-up of a European Parliament permanent IFRS team which has already been a helpful forum to discuss IFRS-related issues.  Regarding the governance of the bodies developing and advising on the standards, in our reply to the IFRS Foundation’s consultations on their structure and effectiveness, we passed a strong message to improve the public accountability of the IFRS Foundation. We wish to see a more active Monitoring Board on issues of public interest, an allocation of top jobs to countries that fund it and use its IFRS standards, and a strengthened effects analysis.  For EFRAG, the appointment of the President of the Board in the coming weeks will be the last step of the reform. Following the withdrawal of Wolf Klinz and the need for another selection procedure, the Commission selected Jean-Paul Gauzès. We are pleased to note that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs agreed on 30 May to support Mr Gauzès’s nomination.  In parallel, our services are intensively working with EFRAG to establish a sound basis for a solid effects analysis methodology which we would like EFRAG to apply in support of their future endorsement advices. Consequently, I am counting on the support of the European Parliament to ensure a rapid adoption of our proposal to extend the co-financing of EFRAG for the period 2017-2020 along the same lines as was earlier agreed with Parliament with respect to the IFRS Foundation and the PIOB (Public Interest Oversight Board). Regarding the request for clarification of certain endorsement criteria such as ‘the public good’ and the ‘true and fair’ principle, I am pleased to inform you that our services have had very constructive and substantial discussions with representatives of the Member States in the Accounting Regulatory Committee. We have reached common grounds on these issues in that Committee. The case law has been analysed and the Maystadt report was taken into account. We will shortly publish the outcome of these discussions and we would be happy to discuss our findings with Parliament, to start with in the European Parliament IFRS team, if you like.  In this context, I would like to mention that at this moment, we see no compelling need to review the existing legislation. On balance, the endorsement process works well and I believe we can bring meaningful improvements with respect to the endorsement process, including with respect to the application of concepts such as ‘public good’ and ‘true and fair’, without the need to legislate, by providing stakeholders and those involved in the standard setting process with the necessary clarifications.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – International accounting standards are an essential element for the efficient functioning of the market and have contributed to a general improvement in the quality of accounting data and statements, benefiting both the single market and capital markets. I believe that some improvements are still needed, as the Member States do not fully implement these standards or do not fully support them. Common guidelines should be developed and member states should be encouraged to follow them and implement them fully. I also consider it important to develop simplified pan-European accounting standards for SMEs, enabling them to increase cross-border mobility, lower costs and easier access to finance on capital markets.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, when I set out to write this report, my aim was to have an end product that reflected the reality of the situation and was useful. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation and efforts in helping to achieve this. I believe we have a report that is strongly supported across Parliament. It deals with a critical issue bearing on so many current concerns in our countries. We have seen flows of refugees and economic migrants, as well as the terrorist threat, increasing – and, by the time these problems are on the doorstep of Europe, it is too late. It is therefore in our interest not only to put our own houses in order so that we reduce the pull factors and our own vulnerabilities, but also to help the African countries, in particular, to deal with their problems. It is thus in all our interests for African countries, and the African Union in particular, to do more to create peace and stability on their continent, but they need help to achieve this, particularly in building capacity. A key priority is to make the African Standby Force operational and really effective as soon as possible. This requires stronger political will and engagement from the African countries themselves, more advocacy by us in African capitals and practical assistance by our Member States and – in terms of funding and civil resources – by the EU itself. So often, Parliament’s reports give the impression that the EU alone is shouldering the world’s problems. This is far from the truth. We need to recognise the efforts of the United Nations, the African Union, the United States and NATO, as well as many individual European countries, in addition to the excellent contribution from the EU itself. The EU must also avoid duplicating the work of others. There needs to be greater cooperation and communication between all those involved. Given the scale of the challenges and the complex involvement of other organisations and nations, the EU should seek an appropriate division of labour, focusing on where it can best add value, including through support to operations by individual Member States. There is probably sufficient funding available to Africa and for peace support operations. It is a question of how it is spent. There is a requirement for greater transparency and accountability in order to give assurance about appropriate spending. We have a duty to ensure funds are not abused or wasted. The EU should focus its efforts: it needs to prioritise. There are a great many issues to be dealt with and it would be most effective to be selective in the ones we attempt to tackle. Our engagement over the years in helping overcome the problem of anti-personnel landmines, which have been such a threat in post-conflict development, is a case in point. I do not happen to believe that promotion of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) agenda is the right focus. Others are better able to provide military support. The EU can be useful in other ways. I therefore do not support the references to the CSDP that have been made through amendments to my report in committee. In order for peace support operations (PSOs) in Africa to be effective in bringing about real change, there must be a consistent drive towards a more coordinated response by all international actors. The UN must carry the main responsibility for external military intervention, but the African Union must increasingly take the regional lead, supported by the most capable of our nations, as well as by the United States, NATO and the EU as appropriate. Enhanced international collaboration, appropriate division of labour and a continued emphasis on African capability and responsibility must be our priorities. The needs of the African countries concerned and the security and cohesion of our own countries should be the overall guiding principles for EU involvement.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is a good report. The result of working with General Van Orden is a report which, on the one hand, is critical and, on the other hand, undoubtedly assesses well all that has happened in Africa from the point of view of various missions, not just European ones. But, very importantly for me, this criticism is mainly to make these missions, in short, better, better functioning, so that the actual higher efficiency of this whole effort guarantees an improvement in the situation in Africa. I would also like to emphasise that, with the criticism of the rapporteur, it has been possible to establish the right proportions regarding Europe's proper involvement in the mission in Africa in general. I think that, in general, this report will be a source or an opportunity for our missions, for which we bear certain costs, to be more efficient, more efficient and more important for Africa.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the moment there are 16 UN peacekeeping operations on various fronts of the planet, employing around 120 000 people. Africa is the point of greatest commitment to the difficult peace-building effort, a continent ravaged by countless conflicts, and the cost of these conflicts is in millions of deaths, endless destruction, the blocking of any development process and the mass exodus of people to Europe. European countries and the European Union itself are important contributors to the UN system, in particular through financial support for UN programmes and projects. Much more needs to be done to overcome the challenges we face. The current action of the United Nations must therefore be strengthened and made more incisive by the contribution of all countries with technical and economic resources. Europe and the international community must be able to meet this challenge, not only through peace missions but above all through the necessary action to prevent conflicts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, foreign intervention is and will remain reprehensible no matter what form it takes. In the name of supporting peace, countries were dismembered, entire societies were condemned to underdevelopment and peoples disappeared. The assessment of recent interventions and interventions in Africa is no exception to this description; interventions unsuccessful even from a military point of view. What happened in Somalia, the Sahel, Libya? These examples are not random. They are three areas in which, after foreign military intervention, Salafis Islam became stronger. In other words, the Iraq scenario was repeated in full.  But decisions come at a cost, especially irresponsible decisions, particularly from France, whose successive governments and eminent so-called intellectuals are trying to drag the whole of Europe into catastrophic wars in Africa. So let France assume its responsibilities, especially in relation to refugees and migrants who drown every day off the coast of Crete and Lampedusa. Let it also undertake the reconstruction of the countries it has destroyed and let it not charge the other states a share of its own deadlocked diplomacy that it has held for years.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam Presidents, the United Nations, the European Union and the African Union are the key to success for stability and for a safer future for the African continent. But there should be invited to other countries, should be invited, and are already engaged of course, both the U.S. and China which has several thousand troops ready at all times to help in Africa. Those are good examples. What NATO does, those are good examples. What our countries do, the European Union has spent 1.5 billion euros in demining after various wars in the last 20 years. These are things we need to highlight, but of course we should also highlight serious problems.  Eco-migrants are what's happening to us today, and even more will happen tomorrow. Eco-migrants will be increasingly due to climate change and it is high time we took concrete steps to stabilise and keep safe in Africa.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, contrary to the prophecies of the 1990s, which heralded an era of peace, security and prosperity, we now live in a more dangerous world, with more wars, more inequality and misery.  These wars, often disguised with humanitarian intentions, reflect the need for rich countries to master large reserves of raw materials and therefore foment corruption. Africa is tired of interference, it is tired of corrupt governments supported by multinationals with the connivance of capitalist countries. She is tired of successive interference maneuvers in which weapons are poured on the African continent and fratrited wars are fomented to the satisfaction of the large multinationals of the industrial military complex.  Africa calls for a new paradigm in international relations, a paradigm based on respect for national sovereignty, respect for self-determination, the right of each people to be able to dispose of their resources and choose their own development model.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, Commission President Juncker famously said that a European army will be necessary in the long run. This report, written by a British Conservative MEP, does not support a common security and defence policy. It is pro-EU enough in a lot of ways, because it talks about strengthening EU military cooperation, but it stops short and deliberately does not support a common security and defence policy. And of course what we have in this Chamber is amendment after amendment putting all of those things back in, because the European Union wants to move inexorably in that direction, towards a European army. So if anyone is in any doubt that that is the direction of travel, all you need do is look at the amendments to this report.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you very much for your kind invitation to attend this presentation and for the exchange of views. I very much welcome Mr Van Orden’s report on EU engagement with the United Nations and the African Union in peace support operations. I also very much appreciate the close involvement of both the Committee on Development and the Subcommittee on Security and Defence on this important issue, which falls at the intersection of security and development. The UN and the African Union are our strategic partners in preventing conflicts, promoting stability and building peace in Africa, including through the deployment of peace support operations in crisis and post-conflict scenarios. Peace and security is a priority area of cooperation under both the Africa-EU Strategic Partnership and the new EU-UN Strategic Partnership. African-led peace support operations receive substantial financial support from the European Union under the African Peace Facility (APF). As noted in the report, stronger emphasis will now be given to building the African Union’s own capacities in order to enable it to respond to and manage crises by itself. The establishment of the African Standby Force is an important milestone in this regard. Let me also recall that, through the APF, we provide support not only to African-led missions, but also to the overall African Peace and Security Architecture and to the Early Response Mechanism, which plays a critical role in conflict prevention and resolution by enabling African mediation and preventive diplomacy actions. We are working hard to ensure the financial sustainability of the APF, which is being called on to provide support to an increasing number of peace and security operations. But this needs fairer burden sharing with our African and international partners, as called for in the report. We raised this important issue at the recent meeting of the Commission with the African Union Commission. EU crisis management missions and operations in Africa, under our Common Security and Defence Policy, are also closely coordinated with the UN and AU, particularly when deployed in parallel to UN and/or African Union peace support operations, for instance in Somalia, the Central African Republic (CAR) and Mali. We maintain regular contacts with the African Union and the UN at all levels, from the planning stage to the end of the implementation stage, not only in the headquarters but also in the field, in order to ensure an efficient division of labour, to share relevant information, including on situational awareness, and, indeed, to conduct joint conflict analysis, for instance in the CAR. Cooperation with the UN in building African Union peace and security capacities is also close and fruitful, not only in crisis management, early warning and mediation but also in policy areas such as security-sector reform and disarmament, demobilisation and the reintegration of ex—combatants. When building African capacities in police and criminal justice matters, we also discuss with the UN relevant principles and approaches. Beyond the specific case of Africa, we also welcome the draft report’s support for the objectives of the recent Joint Communication on Capacity Building for Security and Development, which aims at better enabling our partners to prevent and manage crises by themselves, acknowledging the need to provide support to both the civilian law-enforcement services and the military, particularly in conflict-affected countries.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am pleased that today, almost a year after the start of work on the project, I can present a final report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain. The report was started by Dawid Jackiewicz, now a minister in the Government of the Republic of Poland. I would like to emphasise the significant contribution made by both the Member and his colleagues and the staff of the Secretariat. The involvement of Members from different political groups, in particular shadow Members, was also important for the final shape of the report. Thank you all very much for your time and activity. I am aware that the subject matter of the report is extremely important, both for distributors and suppliers, and that its final text and message will be of great importance for the future of relations between the two groups.  In the report, we have made it clear that UTPs are a problem that is confirmed by all actors in the food supply chain and national competition authorities. Concrete examples confirm the importance of this problem, including in the UK and Poland. A number of meetings have taken place during the work on the report, both with international and national organisations. A number of suggestions and experience have been made on the functioning of both voluntary and legislative solutions at national level. The Commission and Parliament have repeatedly highlighted the problem of UTPs, including in the Commission's report of 29 January. We do not know the opinion on it, but we know that the opinions are divided. For example, the review of solutions to tackle UTPs in the Member States confirms that voluntary initiatives are currently proving insufficient. The report makes recommendations to support the need for hard work on solutions to improve the relationship between suppliers and supermarkets, including minimising the fear factor. We have also called on the Commission to take action to formulate new tools to strengthen action to combat unfair practices. Almost all Member States have put in place regulatory arrangements to complement good practices. Today we can already say that, in the context of the Commission's report, the experience of other countries described confirms that voluntary initiatives can only have a complementary effect. However, the initiatives currently in place are fraught with the shortcomings that we point out in the report. Most countries have recently introduced their own national regulations. Member States should therefore be encouraged to exchange experience on regulatory solutions. You should also ask if that is enough. I believe that the joint content of the report will be a significant step in tackling unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain. We all want the relations between the trading environments to be transparent and equal. I therefore hope that, during this parliamentary session, you will vote on the draft report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Madam President, I believe that the European Parliament must be clear on this issue. We must support and shield consumers, producers and small and medium-sized enterprises from the unfair practices applied in the food chain and in trade by the various large enterprises. I believe that we are all consumers and we know that the weak link in this food chain is consumers, above all, producers but also small and medium-sized enterprises. This large food supply chain plays an important role in economies and society, accounting for 4.3% of the European Union's Gross National Product and 17% of small and medium-sized enterprises. We therefore support, strengthen and seal the framework, strengthen competition law and the institutional framework that must be in favour of the consumer, protect him, respect the rights of the consumer, give him great transparency. With all these weapons I believe that we can reverse unfair practices in this important and sensitive aspect that has to do essentially with all of us consumers but also with the food we supply every day.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Madam President, many actors in the food supply chain have encountered delays in payment, unilateral changes to the terms and conditions or the transfer of costs by a business partner. Voluntary initiatives at national and European level, in which some market players are committed to fair behaviour, have demonstrably suffered from a number of shortcomings. They cannot therefore be regarded as an instrument against the abuse of unequal status.  Given the increasing fragmentation of rules in the internal market, we need a single European framework that defines common principles in the fight against unfair trading practices. This report calls for a fair competitive environment across Member States to enable markets to function as they should. It requires setting up fair and transparent relationships between manufacturers, suppliers and distributors. It also calls for improved limited cooperation between national supervisory authorities in order to improve the fight against cross-border cases. Balancing bargaining power throughout the chain will strengthen competitiveness, contribute to sustainable development and a diverse selection of quality and accessible food for end consumers.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, UTPs in the food supply chain are numerous and everyday, so I am extremely pleased that the rapporteur approaches this problem in a serious and comprehensive manner. In particular, I would like to highlight one problem faced by all small producers in Croatia, which is the imbalance of bargaining power that has an adverse effect on contract freedom, diversity of supply and price. Namely, large distributors and retail chains use market disorder and their dominant position on it in order to bring down the purchase price as much as possible, which small producers simply cannot survive. The rapporteur offers a quality solution in the form of the establishment of producer organisations that would put small producers in a more favourable negotiating position and I absolutely support it, but we must be aware that without a much stronger role of the competent authorities of the Member States in informing and redressing small producers, this model will hardly fully live up to and give the expected results.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, we need efficient tools to deal with imbalances in the food sector in order to ensure fairness, transparency and trust. The Supply Chain Initiative is a good process. It is gaining ground. Now we need to show concrete results on impartial governance, confidential claims and sanctions. It is about creating a culture of compliance in the Member States. And the solution is enforcing rules, such as the Late Payment Directive, rather than creating new rules which could burden SMEs even more. Competition law is a key, in food retail as elsewhere, to ensuring a level playing field. The Commission has been clear that, on the basis of independent study and years of work together with us, EU legislation unfortunately does not solve the problem. Colleagues, I call on you to vote against EU legislation on unfair trading practices. Let us not give our dear farmers, SMEs and consumers, who have legitimate concerns, the illusion of a quick fix from Brussels.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, isn't it strange that in our markets we have a fair trade label for cocoa imports, for the import of coffee, and then in our own market our producers come to a situation where they do not have fair trade, and that they are not in a situation where they can defend themselves against attacks, from violence almost, which we have on the market. We are for the free market, but we are not in for freedom of violence in that market, because we want fair competition. Only fair competition, especially those that are smaller, weak, but which are the key to the diversity of our tastes and smells in our European agriculture, it is these small producers that carry diversity and diversity in Europe and we must protect them in the market, precisely in the way that this report proposes, but also in the way that member states have to do it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in the face of successive complaints from producers who survive, those who survive, with the rope in its throat, the European Commission has the peculiar and very convenient understanding that, by definition, there is no dumping in the internal market.  But the truth is that products at impossible prices continue to appear on supermarket shelves every day, lower than the production costs that devastate producers, which tend to wipe out entire domestic production sectors.  The examples are too much! Take the case of cheese from central Europe for sale in Portugal, on large commercial areas, at prices that do not even pay the cost of milk from which it was made. The truth is very different from the European Commission's version. Dumping not only exists but is inherent in the functioning of the internal market.  A market tailored to the large economic groups, including those of the large distribution, of their imperial and colonizing drive, which destroys production systems and producers and helps to level down living and working conditions in Europe.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – According to some data, unfair trading practices are expected to cost European consumers as much as €30 billion a year. Undoubtedly, micro- and small and medium-sized enterprises are most affected by such practices and, of course, by farmers who are most affected. The statistics are also very eloquent, pointing out that virtually five traders in Europe control as much as 50% market share. It is therefore a practice that is not good for fair competition and, of course, they can feel, as I said, small, medium-sized enterprises, farmers as well as consumers. That is why we want European legislation to regulate this in a more efficient, fair way, but of course there is also a lot in the Member States. Of course, the solutions to date are not ideal, and what we will be voting on in the coming days is not an ideal model. It may be a step forward, but we wish this practice... above all, for the European Commission to draw up an even more ambitious plan and measures to protect small, medium-sized enterprises, farmers and, ultimately, consumers.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The report reveals a number of mechanisms that implement unfair commercial practices in the food chain. In particular, it underlines that prices should better reflect the added value of primary producers. I would now like to point to an unfair trade procedure which is not mentioned in the report: the difference in the quality of goods sold on the Eastern and Western markets. In this regard, sixty of us, Members, have submitted a statement in writing. There are clear studies showing that the same product, in the same packaging, for the same price, is of much lower quality when sold on the Eastern markets. They said that eastern, central and eastern European countries do not enter the EU as second-class citizens. And these companies think that in this House of Europe, we should not be in the drawing room, but in the maid's room. This practice cannot be accepted.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, can I thank the rapporteur for his work on this and for his cooperation with our colleagues in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development where I drafted the opinion? Clearly this is on the agenda, because it is a problem, I recall that since 2009 there have been five resolutions on this issue before the House, and it is still before us this evening. There are differences as to how you tackle it. Can I just say in relation to the Supply Chain Initiative that the reason it exists at all is because there was political pressure on the powerful in the food supply chain to take action. They would not have done so without consistent pressure from this House. Anna Maria Corazza Bildt was involved in this, as was I, with other colleagues as well. I hope this House will give a strong signal to the Commissioner who is with us this evening that there will be EU action and attention to this issue. It is about producers and consumers, because consumer choice is impacted where the powerful have too much power, and when we want sustainable food supply chains, with an eye to the environment, we need those chains to be fair.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, farmers are currently suffering from a price crush which in some sectors, such as milk, are at historically low levels. In addition to unfavourable market conditions, farmers' relationship with industry and distribution reveals differences in terms of trading capacity, resulting in lower prices they receive.  In view of the need to ensure the disposal of their products, farmers are often impelled to accept conditions that force them to revise their income forecasts down. There is an urgent need for European legislation to rebalance this relationship and ensure a fair price for farmers. This issue acquires a particular importance in the case of regions whose production depends heavily on the distribution to drain their products, as is the case in the Azores.  I would therefore like to welcome the commissioner's visit this week to the Agriculture Fair in Portugal, where a meeting is scheduled for the President of the Regional Government of the Azores.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am taking this report this evening on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Bieńkowska. The Commission would like to thank the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection for this report on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. In particular I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Czesak, for his hard work on this report. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs from other committees, in particular Ms McGuinness, for their input. I fully share your views about the importance of the food supply chain. It affects all of us as European citizens so it is crucial that the chain functions well. There are very large and very small players operating in the food chain, and commercial relationships between these companies usually work reasonably well. Of course, negotiations can sometimes be tough but what we need to avoid is companies’ abusing large differences in bargaining power to apply unfair trading practices. I fully agree with you that this is not acceptable. For the agricultural sector I have asked the Agricultural Markets Task Force to further assess the issue of unfair trading practices and I look forward to their conclusions and their recommendations later this year. As you know, unfair trading practices have been a hot issue in many Member States in recent years. Your report acknowledges the numerous initiatives that have been taken to address the issue. We reported on this in January: we found that 20 Member States had introduced legislation against unfair trading practices and more were planning to do so. Obviously there is a problem when so many Member States have acted in a legislative way. Where Member States have identified a major problem they have introduced comprehensive and strong enforcement measures. It is true that Member States have taken different approaches on the issue. Most of these national frameworks are quite recent. So I agree that we should continuously monitor and assess these national frameworks to see if they are working or not. And that is what we will do. An important achievement in the fight against unfair practices was the launch of the EU voluntary Supply Chain Initiative. Your report welcomes this initiative but points to a number of weaknesses. You suggested that, because of these, farmer representatives have not joined the scheme. We agree that the initiative was a step in the right direction and commercial issues cannot always be solved by regulation alone. Any measure that aims to build trust between the parties should be given a serious chance. And we agree with you that there are very concrete points that can and must still be improved. So we will work together with all relevant stakeholders to make this happen. As voluntary efforts go, this is give and take. We hope that farmer representatives will reconsider joining the initiative so that they can prove its value and can make their case within it. We welcome Mr Czesak’s report, we will reflect in detail on its suggestions, and together we need to focus on actions that can truly make a change and add value, and I am committing myself to do so in conjunction with the report of the Agricultural Markets Task Force later this year.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – Unfair trading practices (UTPs) can affect small food producers and retailers in business relationships where one party is in a stronger position than the other. UTPs are often regarded as practices that deviate from good commercial conduct or are contrary to good faith and fair dealing imposed from one trading partner to another. These practices can have a negative effect on the EU economy as a whole, resulting in SMEs losing their ability to invest and innovate and a failure to seek expansion in the single market. The issue has come to our attention in recent years with many Member States installing self-regulatory frameworks and providing examples of best practices. However, the problem of UTPs is growing and becoming more widespread, and voluntary procedures will not be enough to solve the issue. Consistent action from the EU is needed to eliminate UTPs in the food supply chain and to protect small producers. This can be done through defining what UTPs consist of and the penalty for their use, as well as encouraging Member States to exchange best practices. The problem of unfair trading internally in the EU must be dealt with to protect fair competition and prevent worsening effects on the EU economy.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the own-initiative report and the call for stronger regulation so that food producers and retailers can be adequately protected against unfair trading practices. It is now up to the Commission to look closely at how we can establish a single framework against unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, so that we can ensure fair and transparent relations between all those involved in the food supply chain.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Unfair commercial practices in business-to-business relationships have come to the fore in recent years, and while it is difficult to assess the importance of the problem, there is a significant amount of statistical and market-based evidence to suggest that unfair commercial practices are relatively prevalent, particularly in the food supply chain. Many Member States have recognised that unfair commercial practices are causing harm and have taken measures to combat them. However, there are also significant differences in the rules between Member States in this area, and the scale of the problem varies.  In my opinion, due to the scale of the problem, EU legislation should be adopted to ensure the proper functioning of the markets and fair and transparent relations between all participants in the food supply chain. I believe that decisive, consistent measures must be taken to eliminate unfair trade practices once and for all in the EU food supply chain.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – As a Member of Polish I am very positive about the report on unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain. UTPs in the food supply chain, which start mainly from economic imbalances in trade relations, have a significantly negative impact on the entire Economy of the European Union. The abuse of a stronger market position by large companies deprives small and medium-sized enterprises of their ability to invest and thus blocks the development of this sector of the economy in the EU single market. The prevalence of UTPs and their application to small food producers and retailers shows the weakness of existing self-regulatory mechanisms in order to restore market equilibrium. Not without impact on the ineffectiveness of these mechanisms is the "fear factor" raised in this report, which in a sense forces small and medium-sized producers to submit to unfair practices for fear of severing trade relations by a stronger party - a large corporation. From here, therefore, I call for decisive action to be taken to completely eliminate unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain in the European Union.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Writing. – If milk is sold cheaper than water, that is a scandal! The slingshot pricing policy at the expense of farmers must end. Trade groups, which are giving away milk and meat as a lure below the cost price, are passing on sustainable food production at the expense of our farmers and consumers. Our farmers do not need any further analysis and stocktaking of unfair trade practices in the food trade, but EU framework legislation that systematically combats producer blackmail and undercutting competition! The supremacy of the corporations causes farmers to delay payments, unilateral treaty changes and advance payments to supermarkets as an entry fee. This has nothing to do with a market economy. The Commission must therefore act swiftly with effective enforcement mechanisms and effective sanctions to counteract this fatal aberration. Quality food comes at a price. The status quo, however, means simply maximising profits of trading groups and their lobby. This opens the door to mass production. But I'm not for that. Both our farmers and consumers are entitled to the long-term production of top-quality food in Europe.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – I advocate that the problem of unfair trading practices that are cancers early in European and Croatian agriculture be solved by adopting the Law at the EU level, because it has been shown that the voluntary approach to this problem does not give results. Endlessly long payment deadlines and unilateral changes or terminations of contractual obligations by retail chains should be put to an end.  When it comes to competition, measures targeting producers are often adopted, while the UTPs and their concentration are tolerated almost to the level of monopoly. Farmers are brought to the beggar's stick by such reckless and unfair treatment.  Does anyone wonder what these people live on and what do they school their children from, if they are not paid for their products for a year or if they are returned overnight under the pretense that they are not good enough just because imported cheaper and lower quality goods pushed out their product? As we have a common market, this problem needs to be addressed at a common, EU level. Law. And I'm going to do it now!

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - UTPs are a serious problem present in a number of economic conflicts. The importance of the food supply chain is high for the Union, as the sector employs more than 47 million people, with a share of up to 7% in gross value added at EU level. Generally speaking, UTPs can be defined as a practice that grossly deviates from good business conduct. In my view, UTPs are an obstacle to the development and good functioning of the internal market.  Consumers can remain deprived of the variety of offers. This practice has serious negative consequences for farmers, such as reduced profits, higher costs than anticipated, overproduction and food waste, and financial planning difficulties. This practice occurs where there are imbalances in financial resources, and I believe that it can have a detrimental effect on the Union economy as a whole, as it can lead to companies, in particular SMEs, losing their ability to invest.  I believe that adopting common standards, as a means of combating this practice, will enable a labour market where there are fair and transparent relations between all parties involved in the food supply chain.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, let me start by saying how much I have really appreciated the support and cooperation of all the Groups and the shadows in producing this report. It is estimated that there will be nearly 2.5 billion more people on the planet by 2050 than there are today, so satisfying the demand for safe, healthy and nutritious food is one of the biggest challenges facing our world. Land availability is shrinking; we have environmental degradation, shortages of water and increased energy demand, not to mention the emergence of new pests and diseases – all of which are putting real pressure on the natural environment. So we need to develop technological solutions not only to increase production, but to improve the means of distribution and to tackle food waste, and the benefits of innovative technologies need to be applicable and available to all our farmers whether they are conventional or organic, livestock or arable, small scale or large scale. Concern about food security has brought a new focus to public sector research and development in recent years, but European agriculture continues to trail behind many of its international competitors. What we need is sustained and prioritised investment in applied and translational research. Not enough research is commercialised, and that means that farmers are not able to take advantage of the opportunities that innovation could provide, Take precision farming, for example. My report calls on the Commission and the Member States to work in partnership to improve the performance and adaptability of PF techniques.  Agriculture accounts for 70% of the world’s freshwater use – 70%. Now this can be significantly reduced by the use of precision irrigation techniques. My report welcomes the inclusion of PF robotics in Horizon 2020 and encourages the uptake of GPS-driven machinery and drones. It welcomes the development of controlled traffic farming technologies which reduce soil damage. It welcomes efforts to integrate high-resolution remote sensing technology into organic farming.  The report also covers the need for continuous progress in innovative breeding aimed at increasing not only the range of pest- and disease-resistant traits in crops, but also the range of food raw materials with nutritional and health beneficial characteristics on the market. The loss of genetic diversity over the past century threatens our food and feed security, so all plant varieties, animal species, land races, wild and semi-wild relatives, they are all essential for maintaining genetic diversity. And we should be encouraging an open and transparent dialogue among the stakeholders and the public on responsible development of high-precision innovative solutions for breeding programmes, including risks, hazards and benefits. We need to raise awareness and understanding of new techniques among farmers and the general public, and we have to make sure that consumers and farmers are sufficiently educated about new breeding techniques to ensure that open and informed public debate can take place.  Europe should be a world leader in agricultural technology. Farmers are the major stewards of our environment and they need continued access to innovation, new technology and research in order to produce food in a sustainable way. So we need all to work together – the EU and the Member States, academia such as Harper Adams University in my region, the industry, breeders, agro-chemical sectors, all work together to make sure that we have the best research and we translate it practice, from lab to farm to fork. That will unlock a new phase in agricultural innovation in Europe.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has In order for European agriculture to continue to play a prominent position in technology, innovation and sustainability in a global comparison, we must make it fit for the future. In my opinion, this requires: firstly, resources already in precision agriculture, which improve the effectiveness of the funds used. Secondly, the inclusion of all forms of agriculture and all regions, in other words favoured areas as well as less-favoured areas and large and small farms, in order to guarantee the sustainable development of the entire rural area. Thirdly, better cooperation between farmers, agricultural companies and research institutions. As far as the points at issue are concerned, new breeding techniques should not be labelled negative from the outset, but should only be subjected to sound scientific analysis. That is why I think it is good that there is also a controversial discussion on this in organic farming research. With this in mind, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good cooperation.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, innovation must be at the service of all types of farm, including those of more modest or family size, for which the outermost regions can be a good laboratory. Innovative solutions can contribute to more effective agriculture in the use of resources that improve farmers' competitiveness. The text we discussed includes references to new breeding techniques. With regard to these, I believe that we cannot adopt an obscurantist position because we must and have an obligation to create an environment conducive to the development of science, but always, and I repeat, always with powerful and very precautionary precautionary measures with regard to the impact on the environment and health of people's animals. It requires more debate and more information so that we do not adopt positions that are too aprioristic. We must not prevent the development and work of research centres in these matters, but we must be very cautious in moving to production and consumption.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the report we are debating raises the crucial question of the survival of European agriculture, namely its adaptation to new technological and economic data. Unfortunately, however, we find that there is no clear reference to the threats facing our agriculture today. How do we legislate to protect the rural economy without identifying the risks? The main risk at the moment is the logic that abolishes designations of origin, the logic that underpins the introduction of genetically modified foods into the markets and, of course, the logic of subsidies for monoculture, the intensification of agriculture and the large agricultural lobbies. After all, the Commission has only had to think a few thoughts in order to enable the Czech Republic, for example, to produce Greek yogurt, Commissioner. That's where we're at! Greek yogurt "made in Czech Republic"! Protection of the agricultural sector and sustainable agriculture therefore means subsidies to the right recipients, it means mild and democratic modernisation of traditional small and organic farming.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – (The beginning of speech is not heard) agriculture, I am for the use of satellites, for the use of digital methods, but I am not in for us all to eat the same, I am not in order to have a situation where our health, our environment will be called into question. Especially, I'm not in the way that those who need fish, which is Africa, these are some countries that are poor, they need fish, but I'm not in it to give them fish, but I'm in for giving them hooks and learn how to fish. So I am not in the way that the European Union, because the world is rapidly growing in population, becomes the only food producer, as suggested in some way in this report. But I am in that really everyone has a hook and everyone can catch fish and feed themselves, that is, that every country, every continent, every family can do it. Therefore, I have reservations according to this report and I will not support it tomorrow.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, the report contains positive and relevant aspects, but it goes hand in hand with reality and reality tells us that today, in the Western world, too much food is produced, you pay to eliminate food products. Today's technology applied to agriculture has become a problem and not in any miracle solution to a problem that is political and will only end with a new economic model of production and distribution. Technology is now at the origin of intensive production that endangers biodiversity and balance our planet. GMOs, the glifusate which the Commission has considered to extend for another seven years, are illustrious children of this technology. We do not deny the need for further research in agricultural practices, but we also have to understand each other.  Agriculture subject to the laws of capitalism and the maximum accumulation of profit can only give rise to increasingly intensive and productiontechnologies. Before talking about technology, it is therefore important to reverse our cap today completely liberalised.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, the EU faces a plateau in productivity and fertility caused by soil degradation and loss of ecosystem functions. Intensive farming and climate change have caused this, so continuing down the same intensive path is not a solution – technical or otherwise. Soil health was in the UK news last week as our Environmental Audit Committee argued that CAP cross-compliance rules for agricultural soil health need greater scope, force and ambition. So we need more, not less, soil protection. But Tory Brexiteers, like George Eustace, wish to see these rules scrapped. Now this report claims to reduce inputs, but then calls for less regulation, the fast-tracking of approvals and so-called ‘enabling implementation’, which may enable agri-businesses to sell more and more quickly, but does little to help farmers, their livelihoods, or the soil.  Many of these so-called solutions are financially impossible for most farmers caught up in high input costs and low farm gate prices. Big businesses’ talk of robotics and satellites is distracting and so far removed from the realities of small farmers that the agri-business lobby and our Tory rapporteur really should get back to Earth.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, of course post-Brexit we will want an agreement with the European Union. Of course we want to continue improving our technology, including robotic techniques, as mentioned by the rapporteur. Of course we want to cooperate in research in a way that is sustainable in the long term.  But the problem with the common agricultural policy is that it is just not fit for British farmers. We are already sending pre-accession agriculture funding to Turkey. We are putting in EUR 4.6 billion and getting EUR 2.9 billion back every year from the common agricultural policy. We are not producing enough food ourselves, and of course there is the perennial problem of red tape. So maybe those are just some of the reasons why a recent poll found that 59% of British farmers want to leave the European Union.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, technological progress is essential for sustainable agriculture in the European Union. Agricultural production based on industrial production principles results in harmful effects on all components of the environment, which is why we need new ways of thinking about technological progress by stimulating what lowers input costs and the cost of production with minimal impacts and risks on the environment, health, food safety and biodiversity. But we also need new, more responsible regulation based on respect for the precautionary principle, especially when it comes to new techniques of breeding and growing herbs.  This report promotes new genetic engineering techniques and calls for an amendment to the EU legislative framework for GMO with a view to facilitating its authorisation, which I strongly oppose. It promotes synthetic chemical pesticides by classifying them as low risk even though they have not undergone a detailed risk assessment process, which I find irresponsible.  I consider respecting the precautionary principle essential in preventing damages that can be far greater than planned profits and that should be taken into account by politicians when proposing reports or laws.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I agree that intensive food production due to population growth must be developed in a sustainable way. An important element of this is the reduction of food waste, which is of varying degrees but on a critical scale in each Member State. To address this, I propose the development of socially minded instruments at EU level.  I consider innovation to be another important element, which I believe will be successful if actual farmers are given the opportunity. I consider the European Innovation Partnership to be good, but it would be good to see concrete results. Of course, all this requires resources, but until then, there is only a theoretical debate going on. I call on the Commission to propose solutions to this.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I certainly support technological development in the field of agriculture, because otherwise agriculture will not be able to meet basic expectations, that is to say feed people, give farmers a dignified and decent income, as well as to ensure safe food and to maintain consumer confidence. I therefore firmly believe that it is essential to pay attention and focus, in particular, on research aimed at putting knowledge into practice. Such research will have a great future if we can interest young people, because they are also the bearers of change. However, I certainly support research that will move towards new innovations in the field of plant protection, research that will ensure food safety, and at the same time research that will also answer the big climate change question that is happening to us. In any case, this whole research needs great transparency, because the key to all this is also to maintain the loyalty of a consumer who believes in safe European food.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Madam President, as regards the McIntyre report, I think it is one thing to support innovation and new technologies for the agriculture sector, but I think it is quite another thing to do that with rather a disregard for farmers’ independence, environmental sustainability, and European rules on food safety.  I am completely in favour of new technologies for agriculture and I am convinced that farmers themselves are very much in favour, too. But I do not understand why modernisation of European agriculture is deemed equal to the genetic modification exceeding the boundaries of the established EU GMO assessment framework; deemed equal to a fast-track approval process for new pesticides, potentially putting human health and the environment at risk; and deemed equal to entrenching a misguided rationale that the EU should feed the world, despite the clear logic in favour of the developing world feeding itself and ensuring its own food sovereignty based on agro-ecological approaches. We need to make clear, and ensure, that the common agricultural policy does not stifle innovation and modern technology; but the process must not compromise human health, environmental sustainability or animal welfare.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, for decades agricultural science has focused on boosting production through the development of new technologies. It has achieved enormous yield gains as well as lower costs for large-scale farming and improved the working conditions of many farmers. But this success has come at a high environmental cost. Furthermore, it has failed to solve the social and economic problems of the poor in developing countries, which have generally benefited the least from this boost in production. Increasingly the power of the retailer in the food chain is eroding the margins of even the most efficient and modern producers, as seen now in the crisis in the dairy sector. No matter what advances we make, the farmer seems to end up with less.  The report also does not address issues of food waste, estimated to be in the region of 30% of production globally. Nor does it address the imbalance in the food chain or the weak position of the primary producer. There is definitely one technology out there that can benefit farmers, and that is social media, which make it possible to connect with customers directly without having to pay massive costs for marketing. We have one such company, Castlemaine Farms, in my constituency, and people are benefiting from it. That is how they will benefit from technology; with quality food.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Ms McIntyre for the initiative to address many issues that have a profound interest for the agricultural sector. This report is one of two reports that we will be discussing this evening regarding the importance of innovation in the development of agricultural production.  I share many of the rapporteur’s views which she has set out and I would like to comment on a few of the issues raised. What is particularly important is that the report focuses on the need for sustainable agriculture in the European Union. The report identifies a number of the challenges facing European agriculture in the decades ahead, not least in terms of global population growth and the increasing demand for food. In view of these challenges and those posed by climate change and the European Union’s commitment to meet the COP21 targets, the focus on sustainability is now more important than ever.  There are a number of aspects of the report that I welcome, including precision farming, soil and nutrient management, skills development and knowledge transfer. I welcome, too, the emphasis on reducing bureaucracy and red tape, all of which is consistent with my commitment to simplify the CAP. There is little doubt that big data and precision farming hold significant promise for the future of agricultural production in Europe, and the report encourages the Commission to stimulate the development and uptake of precision farming and to remove the barriers to the integration of fragmented ICT systems. The Commission is in fact very anxious to encourage more precision farming, but the conclusions of a focus group organised by the EIP network recently were that farmers are hesitant in the use of precision farming for several reasons. They do not want to be locked in by a single supplier of software and/or machinery. They want to retain ownership of their own data and they want to see whether an application has added value before they invest.  In view of the sustainability challenges that food production is facing, precision farming technologies offer many possibilities and we believe that many EIP pilot projects under the Rural Development Programme will show the usefulness of precision farming. Later this month our EIP Service Point will host a seminar to bring together businesses, many of them start-ups, that based their business model on the use of big data in the agricultural sector.  It seems that we all share similar concerns regarding genetic diversity. It is in our common interest to have a wide agricultural genetic diversity, but farmers will opt for the highest-yielding varieties and breeds, and as a result, we have already lost genetic diversity and risk losing even more. We have several tools to prevent this, such as support for in situ conservation – under rural development – and support for research in this area. On top of that, we now have an interesting pilot project made possible by a budget attributed by the European Parliament, on the sustainable use of genetic resources, looking for new market opportunities for certain neglected varieties or breeds. Finally, I would like to come back to the issues of skills development, knowledge transfer and research priorities. Farming is changing and will continue to change, and like many other sectors it is becoming an increasingly knowledge-based industry. As Ms McIntyre’s report says, we need the right skills for this. I note and welcome the importance you attach to the EIP and to on-farm demonstration. Knowledge transfer and knowledge generation are key and we should constantly ask ourselves whether we can improve our policy in this area. I have seen many good examples of innovation and the outcomes of research, and I can see the potential of such developments. However, I am only too well aware that this potential will never be realised unless we can translate the innovation into practical on-farm application, as you have recognised in your identification of the importance of knowledge transfer.  Traditionally we link knowledge generation also to research. In January we had a conference in Brussels to discuss with the sector what the priorities for such a long-term research agenda should be. The outcomes of that conference will certainly be taken into account, both for research programming under the remaining part of Horizon 2020 and beyond. Finally, let me thank Ms McIntyre again for the report, and for the very many very relevant issues that were raised.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – The report on technological solutions in the field of sustainable agriculture in the EU could be supported, taking into account the independence and diversity of FARMERS in the EU, the health and environmental impacts, the reality of climate change and EU food safety law. New technologies and innovation are clearly what EU farmers need to adapt to new and ever-changing conditions and deserve support as such. However, I do not like it when points that do not respect any of the above get into the report on my own initiative, do not take into account the precautionary principle and everything is then interpreted as a unified position of Parliament. The report is not acceptable in its current form, inter alia, because it says 'A', but it will no longer complete the 'B'. The report talks about malnutrition, but does not add that obesity is now an even bigger problem. He talks about food shortages, but he does not add that food waste is an equally fundamental problem. Mrs McIntyre's report also argues that the EU should feed the rest of the world, even though it is clear that local and regional production will be much more important to emerging countries. The rapporteur is clearly unaware of the huge problem of the current agricultural system. It produces food at the cost of enormous load on the planet and as such cannot be applied in the future.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – Technological solutions in agriculture have always created mechanisms for dependence on the farmer of large companies producing and selling phytosanitary products, seeds or chemical fertilizers. The challenge of feeding a growing global population is not to increase crop yields through more application of fertilizers, genetically modified organisms or more insecticide pressure, but by reducing food that is thrown away. FAO estimates that 33% of the world's food is wiped out in the trash. Technified agriculture results in the relocation of production of consumption centres, by the requirements of extension and reduction of labour, which means continuing to destroy local employment and increase CO2 emissions. In a world in transition to energy-sustainable, it is time for agriculture to begin its journey towards truly sustainable production, and organic agriculture is the future of sustainable production. In addition, to grow continuously despite the economic situation, both in number of farmers and on the surface, driven by increasingly responsible citizenship, so organic farming is the environmentally sustainable solution that Europe must enhance.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. In the context of climate change, the rising food need resulting from population growth and threats to the environment, it is clear that innovation in agricultural technologies is essential to address these challenges, I am fully aware of this. However, the text voted this noon is not acceptable as it puts forward a pro-industrial, dehumanized, pro-pesticide, pro-GMO vision.  I am, for example, particularly shocked that there is a heavy emphasis on significantly increasing food production. As a reminder, today we produce food for 14 billion people, whereas we are only 7.2 billion. The report does not even mention the fight against waste, the issue of obesity or overeating that more and more people are suffering from. Nor is there anything about the deep agricultural crisis, the precariousness of the work of the land or the state of exhaustion which, too, seriously jeopardizes food production for decades to come.
