On the other hand, proposal is made of light procedures for authorizing pesticides and GMOs in disguise. This text gives the impression of having been written by the industrialists themselves. I refuse to participate in this!

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Rapporteur. – We always talk about problems here, but one of the bigger causes of this is often politics itself. There are huge opportunities and farmers are desperate to make the most of them. It's our job to give them the space to take those opportunities. That is what my report is about.  I am grateful to you, my colleagues in the Committee on Agriculture, for the hard work you have put in to make the report better. Climate change, declining biodiversity, scarcity of natural resources such as water and fertile farmland and a growing resistance of antibiotics: the world around us is changing, with associated challenges. This requires new solutions.  Agriculture and horticulture can meet this challenge. Through knowledge and innovations, we can feed the growing world population with ever better food while improving environmental impacts and animal welfare. I'm proud of that. Agriculture and horticulture is still too often seen as something old-fashioned. Nothing could be further from the truth. Our tractors run on GPS, drones monitor our crops, waste streams such as manure can be converted into valuable products for fertilization or energy, and so on. I see it as my job to help farmers get rid of the wrong image. The sector is capable of feeding the world, saving the environment and taking good care of the animals. This can only be done if we give farmers and gardeners the space to innovate.  This is the main message of my report: ample job for innovation and entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector. The potential of the sector is far from being fully exploited. Ill-considered regulation is still too often in the way. Farmers and gardeners can do much more than they like now. It is up to us to give the farmers that space and not to be guided by groups that have made the vile of the farmer and horticulturalist a right to exist. No one knows his farm better than the farmers or the gardeners themselves. So let them think along about how we can achieve the desired goals. We must give them the confidence and space to apply new ideas and innovations. Do not count the farmer and horticulturalist on a checklist of measures that seem to have been devised from behind a desk, but on the actual contribution for people, animals and the environment.  Too many rules we make today are already out of date tomorrow. So make sure that there is room for new applications, for example by granting projects a pilot status. It is agriculture that has the potential to contribute to the economy of tomorrow by closing cycles, making smart use of the power of nature and connecting with the digital economy. In this way, we can fight pests in a natural way by means of insects, follow our products to the plate, give consumers a better understanding of the farming practice, but also bind CO2 in the soil.  My message to the European Commission and the European agriculture ministers is clear. Tomorrow's agriculture has arrived, but too often we are still lingering. Not only politics, but also the sector must take up the gauntlet. My report offers more than enough possibilities.  Tomorrow I hope that all my colleagues will support me in my explicit call for farmers to be at the heart of tomorrow's agricultural policy. Give farmers and gardeners the confidence and space and use their expertise to bring out the best in our farmers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, the continuation of the successful Common Agricultural Policy and maintaining the sufficiency of high quality food production for European consumers also depends on innovation in agriculture. Innovation is needed in the development of techniques and technologies, but also in funding systems and all levels of governance, all to support the security of food supply for europe's inhabitants and to help the sustainability of Europe's rural areas.  I thank the rapporteur for accepting my amendments and thus highlighting in the report the important role of small and medium-sized family farms that make an outstanding contribution to the creation of socially and economically living rural areas and the preservation of cultural and natural heritage.  Contrary to industrial agricultural production as we see it on other continents, the European way of agriculture is almost on a personal level directed towards the consumer and as such, in terms of its added value, is recognised on the global market. I want this relationship between agricultural producers and consumers to survive and continues to evolve underpinned by the innovation of European science and the economy.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, innovation in agriculture requires sufficient investment in research and development and the involvement of farmers in the search for solutions and dissemination of results. Innovative solutions such as those comprising precision agriculture must be at the service of all types of exploitation, they should present a cost/opportunity ratio proportional to the financial capacities of smaller farms, as is the case in those in more remote or outermost areas, where agriculture is an indispensable activity for local employment.  Agriculture, to feed the world, must adapt to the challenge of climate change and make rational use of available resources. To this end, we need innovative solutions based on technology and a different view of traditional practices, in the process in which farmers must be in the spotlight, as key actors of change and subject to proper training.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the modernisation of small traditional and organic crops is the best, perhaps the only response to the American model of agriculture. The American model – what some in Europe are trying to impose on us through TTIR – is certainly very effective only for the giants of the agri-food sector and the lobbies of large producers, but it is disastrous for our environment, our health, future generations. It is disastrous for all the 25 million farmers in the countries of Europe, the majority of which have chosen and managed with hard struggle to maintain another organisation of production. So instead of pulling the rug under their feet, the European Union must support this legacy. There is no good compromise on TTIR. The European production model, based on the small plant, is at the opposite end of what the American and European multinationals are asking for. At a time when sustainability has become an issue and the commitment of most of the world's major economies exists, the destruction of the European productive fabric will be a major setback.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, innovation remains a key priority for meeting the biggest challenges faced by farming today. In the context of climate change, rising food demand, population growth and threats to the environment, we really need to support agricultural innovation in order to increase the productivity and sustainability of the sector. In other words, farmers will need to produce more with less in the future. However, adoption of the new agricultural technologies by European farms has been modest until now. The challenge before us, Commissioner, is therefore to support the transfer of knowledge from researchers to farmers and to make use of innovative techniques by updating the relevant legislation, as well as the creation of new financing opportunities for farmers.  Most of the farms of today have little in common with the farms of the 1950s and, if we get it right, the farms of 2050 will probably differ significantly from the farms of today.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, we are talking about something as important to agriculture as innovation is. Certainly one more element, but not the only one, to try to get the sector to abandon the crisis in which it is mired and in which the policies adopted by the European Commission have a lot to do. Innovation can have many perspectives, and that is why I would like to thank the rapporteur for clearing that innovation and sustainability are not at odds. Innovating also means betting on agriculture that is detached from dependence on agrochemicals, that allows the farmer to be more independent and produce more cheaply and that takes advantage of everything that respect for biodiversity provides us. To bet on sustainable agriculture is not to go back to the past. It is to face the future with responsibility, with research and with the aim of making agriculture effective and durable a safe and permanent source of food. Probably the most revolutionary and most innovative thing is to re-use all the force that nature gives us and from which we have departed for a long time.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Indeed, with regard to the new innovative breeding procedures, it is also important to get a resolution from the Commission as soon as possible in order to prevent an unfounded social rejection. That is to say, when the Commission itself conducts proceedings, it should not be mixed with the social reception of GMOs.  Another important thing is to connect research and practice more effectively. This is the typical case of glyphosate on Parliament's agenda, when there have been many innovative proposals and suggestions on how to replace glyphosate here in this chamber alone, but the world is almost unchanged, because farmers will not know what to do. I therefore believe that the Commission must devote much more energy to delivering the innovations it has acquired to individual farmers and farmers.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, efficient and innovative agriculture is essential if we are to better meet the sustainability challenges faced by farms on a daily basis. The modern agricultural enterprise is linked not only to the production of goods, but to the concept of multifunctionality, product processing, direct sales, educational farms, agritourism. I am in favour of the adoption of management systems based on information and communication technologies, real-time data monitoring, sensor technology and the use of detection systems for the optimization of production systems or precision agriculture. These actions will lead to better control of production phases and greater surrender of cultures. I am therefore a strong supporter of the development of modern farming practices. I believe that they can make a major contribution to making agriculture more attractive to young farmers, and that is why I believe that the Commission must do more to promote innovation in agriculture.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Huitema, for drafting and presenting his report on enhancing innovation and economic development in future European farm management. From a number of conversations I have had with Mr Huitema, I am well aware of his interest in, and support for, innovation and agriculture. Indeed it is something of which I too am very supportive. The challenges facing our sector are such that a greater focus on innovation is essential, and I am pleased to say is happening. Why is innovation so important? Innovation allows the sector to develop new products, new production methods and services, to respond to challenges like climate change, and to address other societal challenges, particularly in the environment, as well as addressing issues around our competitiveness.  We are all increasingly conscious of the need to ensure food security and of the need for a greater focus on more sustainable food production. Mr Huitema has outlined very effectively the main thrust of his report and the proposals that he is making. I have taken very careful note of the many actions which the Commission is asked to take in relation to the issues raised, whether that is in relation to ICT-based management systems, the need to reduce the use of antimicrobials, or the need to stimulate integrated pest management. In relation to those areas in which the Commission is urged to act, I would like to underline the importance of subsidiarity. In many such areas, local conditions require local solutions, and the Commission is not automatically best placed to address all of these issues. Therefore the relevant level of policy intervention may be national or regional. I welcome the acknowledgment in the report that agriculture has always developed new practices and techniques, and I agree also that innovation is a prerequisite for maintaining this progress.  Perhaps it is useful to recall how innovation is addressed in the current policy mix. Both rural development policy and our research policy under Horizon 2020 stimulate and support innovation. Horizon 2020 is the European Union’s framework programme for research and innovation and a majority of support for agriculture and forestry, research and innovation, will be granted under societal challenge too, which includes food security, sustainable agriculture and forestry, marine and maritime issues, and inland water research and the bio-economy. Under our work programmes in 2016 and 2017 for societal challenge 2, in the relevant part in the Horizon 2020 policy, you will also see that we have already addressed many of the issues that are raised in the report. I think that under our work programmes of 2016 and 2017 you will see that Horizon 2020 has the largest research budget ever, with nearly EUR 80 billion funding available for 2014 until 2020, and EUR 3.7 billion euros are allocated to the relevant heading: societal challenge 2. But this is co-managed and co-shared by the Director General of Agricultural and Rural Development and the Director General for Research and Innovation. The total budget for DG AGRI under Horizon 2020 for seven years is EUR 1.5 billion. Four years of Horizon 2020 activities have already been programmed, from 2014 to 2017, representing on the agriculture side 71 topics for a budget of EUR 617 million financing, which is financing an expected 112 projects. 14 have started in April 2015, 22 are scheduled to start in the upcoming months, with others still to be submitted. In the last three years of the Horizon 2020, which is 2018-2020, will be programmed at once by September 2017. Out of the 118 rural development programmes, 94 will support the EIP actions in the current programing period. We also expect 3200 pilot projects to be implemented in 24 Member States. I note that the draft report is concerned about a fragmented implementation of the EIP under the rural development programmes. However, I believe that this is its strength. It is thanks to the subsidiarity engrained in the rural development policy that we can reach out across the whole of Europe with projects that are locally appropriate. We think that the current policy mix is a good one, because you cannot have ‘one size fits all’. We should always look critically at our instruments and policies to see whether we can improve them, and I will be glad to do. Last week I attended the informal meeting of European Union agriculture ministers in Mr Huitema’s native country. While there, I and the Ministers visited the STEK food exhibition in Eindhoven. The exhibition was dedicated to innovation in food production and consumption. While there we saw several very exciting and innovative uses of technology in crop and other food production. I think all of us were impressed with what we saw because it is representative of many of the issues you have raised here this evening: the practical application at farm level of the development of technology and the investment in and value of innovation. One needed nothing more to realise the importance of the issues that have been raised this evening in Mr Huitema’s report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – I congratulate the rapporteur on this complex report. Since agriculture, agricultural practices have undergone either structural or production-related changes, and these changes have made the agricultural sector one of the most dynamic economic sectors, with contemporary agricultural practices being state-of-the-art. I consider it important to develop strategies to prevent and mitigate the negative consequences for agriculture in the European Union through the following measures: an action plan in the most affected areas, the use of plant varieties resistant to the new climate parameters, the adaptation of the calendar of agricultural activities to the new conditions, afforestation, the construction of greenhouses, the management of water resources in agriculture, the greening of polluted land , as well as a future plan to eliminate the causes that lead to climate change by promoting a global economy based on low CO2 emissions, coupled with a promotion of energy security.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – I propose that you vote in favour of the adoption of the Huitema report. Agriculture has always developed new practices, techniques and production methods that have increased yields, improved the adaptability of agricultural practices to new and changing conditions and reduced production costs. Agriculture and forestry are key parts of our world, providing goods and services beyond food production and which can be strengthened by facilitating new developments. I see innovation as a prerequisite for maintaining this development.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Today, the European Union, which is created to guarantee peace and European core values, must respond to many challenges. Nevertheless, several countries want to be part of this community, which insters democratic development but also involves obligations. This community of values was also chosen by Ukraine, which includes Transcarpathia, which has a Hungarian population of 12%, where the coexistence of different nationalities is common.  However, the manifestations of far-right organisations present in the country threaten peaceful coexistence and tranquility. Hungarian memorials are vandalised and fear-mongering marches are held, as on 13 March, when anti-Hungarian words were chanted during torchlight marches on the streets of Uzhhorod, the county seat. This movement, which violates the dignity of Hungarians and European values deeply, is contrary to ukraine's constitution and to the country's commitments under international conventions. Following my written question after the event, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs assured me that human rights and the rights of those belonging to national minorities are fundamentally protected by the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and that this matter will be discussed within the framework of the EU-Ukraine Human Rights Meeting.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Madam President, rights to free movement and work in the European Union are inalienable rights. Unfortunately, many of the honest workers and specialists coming from Eastern Europe are facing the phenomenon of exploitation, and this is inadmissible. In recent years, we have seen countless cases where Romanian workers have been treated as second-class citizens and have fallen victim to abuses incompatible with 21st-century Europe. They did not have the legal instruments at their fingertips that could have done them justice. I believe that it is our duty, in the European Parliament, to raise the alarm about the violation of rights and to ensure that the provisions on labour law are complied with for all those working abroad. Let's say "stop" to any form of modern slavery. Beyond information campaigns to prepare European citizens about their rights and obligations, we need a European horizontal mechanism that can prevent abuses in the Member States. Let's not forget: Romanian workers don't come to the west just because they want a decent wage. They also come because they are badly needed in agriculture, construction, transport, IT, medicine and education. It is obvious that their work adds value to the European economy.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – In just a few days, Slovakia will be presiding over the Council of the European Union for the first time. One of its priorities is migration, although in the past it was the statements made by Slovak officials about refugees that caused embarrassment and misunderstanding throughout the Union. I am glad that the Slovak Government wants to promote a comprehensive approach to the refugee crisis. It must include not only improving cooperation in the protection of external borders and the fight against terrorism, but also seeking an agreement on the status of eligible asylum seekers. Unfortunately, the programme document prepared by the Slovak Government avoids this subject. However, I believe that Slovakia is ready to take the initiative to find a consensus that would dispel citizens' concerns, but at the same time confirm that every human life in Europe is worth it.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the United Nations' vision of achieving zero new HIV infections, zero discrimination and zero AIDS-related deaths, as well as this week's summit aimed at eliminating this threat to public health. Tuberculosis is the number one killer for people infected with HIV. Without proper treatment, seven out of ten people living with HIV and developing tuberculosis will die. Despite this, in recent years we have witnessed a withdrawal of donor support for HIV and tuberculosis programmes in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, leaving many patients without access to medicines. In this region, there is the fastest increase in the number of HIV infections, but also an increased number of chemo-resistant tuberculosis. Moreover, in the European Union, the HIV Action Plan expires this year and the Framework Action Plan for Tuberculosis is outdated. In this context, I believe that, on the one hand, it is time for the European Union and not only to have an integrated policy framework for 2016-2020 on HIV and tuberculosis - as co-infections - and, on the other hand, national governments and the European Commission have a responsibility to achieve the sustainable and effective transition to internal funding for patients' access to the necessary medicines.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to the abuses of the child protection authorities in some European countries, abuses to which several Romanian families have recently fallen victim. This was the case with Botnariu, in Norway, when five children were separated from their families. At the end of seven dramatic months, after protests in twenty-one countries, the Botnariu family will be reunited. Unfortunately, the Barbu family now lives a similar drama in the UK.  Florin Barbu went on a hunger strike in the European Court of Human Rights over two weeks. I call on the British authorities to respect the rights of their two children, Romanian citizens, and I call on the European authorities to act to prevent these family traumas. It is our duty to ensure the balance between the two fundamental principles: the best interests of the child, as set out in Recommendation No. 874/1979, and the need to keep families united in accordance with Article 9 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, we have the biggest decision for a generation before us in the UK and it is our rights at work that are on the ballot paper. Since the 1970s our trade unions have worked in solidarity across Europe to fight to secure valuable working rights for all. It was Ford’s female workers who symbolised the fight for equal pay, but it was the European Court of Justice that guaranteed it in 1982. EU health and safety legislation has saved countless British lives. Rights like maternity and paternity leave, equal treatment for part-time, full—time and agency workers and the right to paid holiday are all underpinned by EU law, avoiding a race to the bottom. And now the leave campaign wants a flexible Britain and a bonfire of red tape and regulation: a bonfire of your rights. Don’t give them that chance. Please vote to stay in on 23 June.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, the two countries in which modern slavery is most widespread today are Uzbekistan and Pakistan. These are two countries with which the EU has close relations. Moreover, the report of the International Labour Organization stated the crucial importance for the authorities of Uzbekistan to continue with measures to keep children away from the cotton harvest, as child labour in cotton harvesting has been widely used before. The EU Parliament has constantly condemned the systematic violation of labour rights in Uzbekistan and Pakistan. The Commission and the Member States have looked away even though forced labour, both adults and children, is a common practice in both countries. The Commission should firmly and resolutely address such cases of human rights violations in these countries and step up the fight against forced labour in Central Asia.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Last week, the lower house of the German Parliament adopted a declaration condemning a serious violence, a serious crime against humanity, namely the Armenian genocide committed by the young Turkish government in 1915. One reaction that shows an absolute discrepancy between all the so-called " European values and the policy currently taking place in Turkey and which conceals the crimes committed at the time by the young Turkish government, which is currently said to be the successor to the Turkish prime minister and president. It is this kind of behaviour that shows a deeply flawed policy on the part of the so-called "no-fly zone." current Leaders of the European Union who make too many concessions to an undemocratic authoritarian power, such as the one in Ankara.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, the EU needs radical reform, hence Sinn Féin’s policy of critical engagement. The best interests of Irish people are not always best served by EU policies and practices. Nor are they best served by taking the North of Ireland out of the EU. The North is a net beneficiary of the EU, our farming community benefits through CAP and direct payments, our students can travel through Europe to study, and our businesses can access a single market of over 500 million potential customers. In addition EU protections guaranteed to workers include equal pay for men and women, protection of holiday hours and maternity rights to name but a few. None of these will be replaced by the British Government. If it is Brexit the North of Ireland will be shackled to Britain and partition copper fastened. Sinn Féin is not a cheerleader of the EU; our interest is always assessing what is in the best interest of the people of Ireland. Therefore Sinn Féin is advocating a remain vote.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, the sharing economy, or collaborative economy, is here to stay. I think that, instead of fighting against it, we need to embrace the opportunities that it brings and ensure that there is a harmonised approach to regulation for Member States in the spirit of the common market and in the interests of European consumers.  European consumers are the biggest users of the sharing economy. A study carried out by the Commission itself found that in France, for example, 36% of consumers had used the collaborative economy, such as Airbnb or Uber – and we know those names so well. In Ireland a similar amount – 35% – of consumers have done so. The sharing economy in Europe is estimated to be worth EUR 10 billion, and forecast to grow to EUR 250 billion over the next decade. It gives consumers and customers choice, it offers flexibility and it provides competition. Those companies involved in the collaborative economy also create jobs and generate business for the local economy.  So I welcome the recent presentation by the Commission that looks to prevent a patchwork approach to regulation by Member States and instead advocates one that allows new business models to develop, whilst protecting consumers, ensuring fair taxation, and addressing employment conditions, by advising how EU law should be applied in the sharing economy.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Madam President, the North-East of England has much to gain by staying in the European Union and conversely the North-East has much to lose if we are to leave. The benefits of staying are clear. The European Union is good for jobs, allowing the North-East access to the world’s largest single market, and the EU is good for investment. As the poorest English region we actually receive more back than we put in. And the EU protects our rights, both as consumers and as workers.  The EU keeps us safe – we are now living through the longest period of peace inside the European Union since the Roman Empire – and the EU is good for our environment and countryside, cleaning up our bathing water, protecting our wildlife and helping us to collectively tackle climate change. If we are not careful and we leave the European Union, it may well be that the only place you will find a sheep farmer from the hills in the North-East of England will be at Beamish Open Air Museum. For the North-East of England and the EU the case is clear; better in, worse out.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, my question here this evening is: Can Irish politicians use the time—honoured excuse and say ‘Brussels made us do it’ when it comes to the payment of water charges? The Water Framework Directive gives Member States a clear opt—out where they can decide, in accordance with established practice, not to apply water charges.  So what are established practices? Well, former Commissioner Potočnik answered that question in 2010 when he clarified ‘established practice’ as being at the time of the adoption of the Directive. That is 2003, not 2010, 2014 or 2016. It is 2003.  In 2014, the European Court of Justice found against the European Commission when it took Germany to court for not charging for certain water services, including consumption. The Court was clear in its judgment. The EU legislature intended to allow Member States to determine the measures to be adopted for the recovery of costs, without extending it to all services associated with water use. The Court further states that the directive does not, per se, impose a generalised pricing obligation in respect of all activities of water use.  In this case, what is good enough for Germany is good enough for Ireland, and those Irish politicians who are trying to blame Brussels while pursuing their own agendas have no legal basis for their argument.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: – Madam President, a recent study shows that one in three children between the ages of six and nine in the European Union is either obese or overweight. The cost of dealing with obesity-related problems amounts to one-tenth of the total health expenditure in Europe. However, no progress is being made to stop this trend. It's inadmissible that the fight against obesity goes through strategies on paper - absolutely nothing concrete. Visible action and concrete results are needed. People need to have everything they need to avoid this phenomenon and danger: concrete information, healthy food at decent prices, protection from misleading advertising, especially for children's products. We recently proposed a pilot project to create an information and learning platform on nutrition. I thought of it as an accessible source of ideas and information that parents can rely on, but also institutions, such as kindergartens, when planning food for children every day. I hope that my fellow Members support this project.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, for millennia rural areas have acted as the main providers of food and numerous other agriculture-related resources. They also accounted for the major proportion of population and demographic growth. Over the years, however, with the advent of the industrial revolution, cities started to attract more and more people from across the country, thereby eventually leading to depopulation of rural areas.  Nowadays in most EU Member States, rural dwellers account for much less than half of the population. Whilst these tendencies may have a positive effect on job creation, education, housing or decreasing transportation costs due to usually permanent resettlement from their native places, rural areas essentially lose their future in every sense. It also harms productivity, especially in agriculture and traditional craftsmanship. Moreover, whole cultural strata become endangered. Central and particularly Eastern European Member States are the ones suffering most from this trend, even more so after 2004.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, today, on the anniversary of the Allied landing in Normandy in 1944, who played an important role in the defeat of Nazism, Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama in a delirium of nationalism raised the issue of Tsamourias, representing, as he said, Albanian citizens descendants of the Chamides, those condemned by Greece as war criminals, since as armed divisions they cooperated during the German-Italian occupation with the SS and Wehrmacht by murdering thousands of Greek civilians. So it is time for Greece to demand war reparations and reparations from Albania for the criminal acts of the Nazi collaborators, especially now that Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama has officially accepted the so-called rights and therefore the obligations and responsibilities of the Chamides. After all, we must not forget that Greece in 1945 did not accept Albania's participation in the Paris International Peace Conference, since Albania, like Germany, had and continues to have responsibility for compensating Greece. At the time Albania was part of Mussolini's Italy, which attacked Greece in 1940 and remained until 1943 as the occupying force of my country.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, yesterday Sunday 5 June there was a major demonstration in Barcelona in defence of the Ebro and its delta. It was a continuation of the great manifestation of Amposta, of which four months will be served precisely tomorrow. The Spanish Government has re-examined a hydrological plan which had already been criticised by all bodies, including European ones, for being contrary to the Water Framework Directive. This has been done by a government that claims to be in office because it does not want to make decisions in social policies, but instead dares to re-attack with its plan the viability of the Ebro and its delta, which it wants to leave with an annual flow of 3,000 cubic hectometers, which are absolutely insufficient to ensure its continuity. Today I would like to join my voice again with that of the thousands and thousands of protesters who are calling on the European Commission to force the Government of Spain to withdraw its nefarious hydrological plan. I hope that the Commission will join this citizen cry in defence of a river vital to that area and in defence of the environment.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, sadly, the dumping of Chinese steel continues across Europe, with David Cameron acting as the ringleader for a small group of irresponsible Member States who continue to block the Commission’s proposal for fairer tariffs. These would save our steel industries. However, I do have some good news. Failing Tata steel plants at Scarborough and Workington have just been bought by the investment company Greybull Capital for one pound, securing the jobs of 225 people in the town of Workington in Cumbria, where my office is based, and ultimately safeguarding 4 000 jobs in the supply chain across the UK and France. It is Labour MEPs who continue to expose the Tory Government’s careless callousness in respect of our proud steelmaking industry. They are working together with Labour MPs, such as Sue Hayman, local council leader Alan Smith, and the trade unions. We all know that the EU works best when mutual cooperation and solidarity prevail between politicians, business leaders and workers.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to talk about how our internal market for copyright works or does not work. In Europe, a system of collective management of copyright is in place to ensure compliance with the right to intellectual property and, at the same time, to ensure that authorised rightholders have some comfort in granting such consents to the use of their works, which are then provided by those collecting societies. The public is to be made available to these works.  However, the problem is that each collecting practitioner represents only rightholders in a particular territory of a Member State. And today it is virtually impossible to obtain consents except for musical works throughout the European Union. I think it would be appropriate for the European Union to consider this issue so that the user can obtain the consent of a particular creator from a specific collecting erich, which can thus also give consent for the whole territory of the EU.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, after systematic threats to Portugal with sanctions, the President of the European Commission said a few days ago that there would be no sanctions for France, because France is France. The president of the Eurogroup, Mr. Dijsselbloem, came to contradict him, but only to demand a heavy hand for everyone.  This is the contribution they make to stability. While some Member States seek to do what they can to lift their economy, European leaders do everything in their power to keep investors nervous and citizens on the verge of a nervous breakdown.  As if the disenchantment with the European project was not enough, as if the crisis of democratic legitimacy was not enough, as if the economic and social disaster that resulted from the ideological option of austerity was not enough, as if this disaster were not the result of the austerity policy that prevents the achievement of the targets, what happens is that the President of the European Commission tells us that after all this is not a union between equals.  The problem is that the consequences are very real and are very concrete and turn out to be an economic sabotage, a sanction in itself, but illegal, a sanction in itself, but not written. So I only ask you, Commissioners, one thing, to do Europe a favour, to sanction yourselves. You deserve it!

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, there are just 17 days until the UK votes on its membership of the European Union. This is a huge decision affecting not just Britain’s future but every other Member State represented in this Parliament. The risks to the UK of leaving are huge: an immediate economic shock and a possible recession; 3.5 million jobs at risk; workplace rights and protections which could be scrapped, and defence and security cooperation weakened. In response to these risks the Leave campaign has had no answers. Now having lost the arguments on the economy and security they have resorted to scaremongering over immigration. Over the past few weeks they have made disgusting and borderline racist claims implying that all immigrants who come to the UK are either criminals or welfare claimants. As an immigrant myself I know that these claims are false and that immigrants make a huge positive contribution to the UK. I also believe that most decent voters in Britain know this as well, and they will see through the Leave campaign’s lies and will vote to remain on 23 June.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, Latvia and Estonia host a large number of stateless people. They are former citizens of the Soviet Union and their children. Stateless people make up 12% of the Latvian population and 6% of the Estonian population. The Soviet Union ceased to exist 24 years ago. The problem of mass statelessness in Estonia and Latvia has not been solved so far. In both countries stateless residents are denied voting rights during national and European elections, in Latvia also during local elections.  Estonian and Latvian residents have collected more than 17 000 signatures in order to submit a petition where they ask Parliament to correct the under-representation of stateless people in the European Parliament. They have very good reasons to advocate change. In the case of Estonia and Latvia, and especially in Latvia, the number of seats allocated to these countries in the European Parliament is disproportionately high at the expense of persons without voting rights. I wish my colleagues to support the expansion of voting rights for stateless residents in Estonia and Latvia.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Mr Juncker, Mr Draghi and company, make an effort to listen carefully to what we will tell you. The struggle of the workers and the Portuguese the Government which diligently applied your guidelines, condemned your policies. The struggle of the workers and the people Portuguese fought a path contrary to the march of history. We have fought and succeeded in eliminating public government pay cuts, increasing the national minimum wage, reducing child care rates, strengthening social benefits, thawing pensions, eliminating the IRS surcharge, phasing out school textbooks, among several other measures.  And last week, the 35-hour schedule in public administration was reset. All this is little, very little, although important. There's a lot more to go and we're going to get a lot more.  Mr Juncker, France is France, for it is, but Portugal is Portugal, a country with more than 800 years of history and with a people zealous of its independence. It will be he who writes by his hands his destiny. Soak your beards!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker went to the Congress of Mayors of France on 31 May to tell them that Europe is them. No, Mr Juncker, Europe is you!  The austerity policy that starves the municipalities is you! Mayors are your victims and you're their executioner. An executioner who laments to them when he claims that France benefits from 27 billion euros of Structural Funds over six years, when in reality, the Union costs France twice as much over the same period. An executioner who mocks them when he tells them, I quote, that "the Commission has a soul", while you are the worthy representative of the financial oligarchy that shamelessly crushes them, as repeated scandals prove: LuxLeaks yesterday, Panama Papers today, transatlantic trade and investment partnership tomorrow. But the mayors are not fooled, Mr Juncker, and they are increasingly joining the ranks of those whom you scornfully call populists and who are in fact patriots.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Madam President, the SYRIZA-ANEL government in Greece, after having paid pensions and insurance rights, also handed over the first residence of the popular family to the funds. At the same time, it implements wild taxation, ensuring hot money for industrialists and shipowners. It is now preparing a new law on working conditions equivalent to those passed in France, Belgium and every Member State of the European Union. It is the so-called 'best practices of the European Union' and its institutions such as the European Parliament, which put workers in the thousands on the road. That is exactly what you call the cracking of collective agreements, the abolition of the 13th and 14th salaries, collective redundancies, restrictions on strike. These are all prerequisites for the recovery of capital. It is the magnet for investments like those just signed by the governments of Greece and France on the backs of the peoples of the two countries. An effective labour popular response can only be given with the organized class struggle to recover losses, the overthrow of the power of capital.
